    If a patient has a large abdomen and experiences diarrhea, the pulse should be weak and thin, but if it is instead tight, large, and slippery, this indicates death. 【Hua Shou said: Diarrhea with a large pulse is contradictory. A large abdomen refers to abdominal swelling.】

    The "Eighteen Difficulties" states: the pulse has three divisions, and each division has four vessels. The hands have Taiyin and Yangming, while the feet have Taiyang and Shaoyin, determining the upper and lower divisions. What does this mean? 【Hua Shou said: This section poses a question, stating that within the twelve main meridians of a person there are three divisions, each containing four vessels. The hands have Taiyin and Yangming, the feet have Taiyang and Shaoyin, thus forming upper and lower divisions. The three divisions refer to the cun, guan, and chi, which separate upper, middle, and lower; the four vessels refer to cun, guan, chi, which pair off two by two, hence each division contains four vessels. The Taiyin and Yangming on the hands and the Taiyang and Shaoyin on the feet indicate upper and lower divisions, where the lung is located on the right cun and the kidney on the left chi, mutually supporting one another, with the lung being above and the kidney below, symbolizing the mother-child relationship. The texts say that the essence is higher than the lung and the essence is lower than the kidney.】[50p]
    Indeed. The hand Taiyin (Yin Metal) corresponds to the Yangming (Metal), while the foot Shaoyin (Yin Water) corresponds to the Taiyang (Water). Metal produces Water, which flows downwards and cannot rise, hence it is in the lower part. The foot Jueyin (Yin Wood) corresponds to the Shaoyang (Yang Wood), which produces the hand Taiyang (Yang Fire) and Shaoyin (Yin Fire). Fire rises upward and cannot descend, thus it represents the upper part. The hand Xin (Heart) governs the Shaoyang (Yang Fire) and produces the foot Taiyin (Yin Earth) and Yangming (Earth), where Earth governs the central part. All of these signify the reciprocal generation and nurturing of the Five Elements.

    [Hua Shou remarks: The hand Taiyin (Yin Metal) and foot Taiyang (Yin Water) are in the lower part because Water is inherently downward flowing. The foot Shaoyin (Yin Water) generates the foot Jueyin (Yin Wood), which in turn generates the hand Shaoyin (Yin Fire) and which governs the fire from the hand Xin. Fire ascends and thus represents the upper part. Fire generates the foot Taiyin (Yin Earth), which resides in the central part and further produces the Lung Metal. This dynamic illustrates the reciprocal generation and nurturing of the Five Elements. This can be interpreted as confirming the structure of the upper and lower parts according to the generative properties of the organs rather than waiting for a predetermined order of generation. Furthermore, there is an elaboration into a tripartite framework, referring to the four difficulties discussed: heart and lung being elevated, kidney and liver being lower, while the spleen symbolizes the central region. However, while the former strictly refers to the organs, this perspective includes both channels and organs. The above questions and answers clarify the classic text, with the following two sections not obscuring each other, leading to suspicions of errors in the source material.][51p]
    The pulse has three divisions and nine qualities; what does each govern? Indeed. The three divisions are the cun, guan, and chi. The nine qualities refer to the superficial, middle, and deep states. The upper division corresponds to the heavens and governs ailments from the chest upwards to the head; the middle division corresponds to humans and governs ailments from the diaphragm down to the navel; the lower division corresponds to the earth and governs ailments from the navel down to the feet, which must be examined and needled carefully.

    [Xie states: This section should be viewed as a response in the "Sixteen Difficulties.” The simplified characters are misplaced here, omitting the context of the three divisions and nine qualities. The phrase about careful examination and needling emphasizes the need to assess the pulse's movement and the underlying illness; hence, it is mentioned as careful examination and needling. The act of needling refers to detecting movement corresponding to the illness. Chen Wannian’s transmission states that "needle quality" has the same meaning as "detecting quality," while some say: needling refers to acupuncture, meaning to examine the division carefully before needling.][52p]
    If a person is ill with stagnation accumulating over a long time, can this be determined through pulse diagnosis?

    Yes. When examining the pulse, if there is stagnation in the right flank, and one feels a knot in the lung pulse, then the more pronounced the knot, the greater the accumulation; if the knot is slight, then the accumulation is also slight.

    If the lung pulse is not detected yet there is stagnation in the right flank, why is this? Even if the lung pulse is not apparent, the pulse on the right hand should be found to be somewhat submerged.[53p]
    Is the method for treating external stubborn diseases the same as for internal accumulation? It seems they are different.

    Yes. When the pulse is stagnant, it stops irregularly when coming and going; this is called stagnation. When the pulse is hidden, it runs beneath the tendons; when the pulse is floating, it runs above the flesh. The methods are thus similar for both interior and exterior conditions.

    If, for instance, the pulse is both stagnant and hidden, it indicates there is no internal accumulation; if the pulse is floating and stagnant, it indicates there is no external stubborn disease. If there is accumulation, the pulse will not be stagnated or hidden; if there is a stubborn disease, the pulse will not be floating or stagnant. This is a case where the pulse does not correspond to the disease, and the disease does not correspond to the pulse, which is classified as a terminal condition.

    The nineteenth difficulty states: the classics mention that the pulse can be reversed or aligned. What does this mean?

    The term "aligned" refers to constancy. The pulse can indeed be reversed or aligned, comparing the two genders. The male pulse is typically upper at the barometric level, while the female pulse is generally lower. A male's pulse at the wrist is usually weak, whereas a female's pulse at the wrist is often strong; this is the distinction between their pulses. Reversal refers to the opposite of their norm. Nonetheless, both genders have their respective consistencies. "Reversal" signifies a deviation from their usual state.[54p]
    Indeed, a man is born in the hour of Yín, which is associated with wood and is yang; a woman is born in the hour of Shēn, which is associated with metal and is yin. Therefore, the male pulse is located at the upper gate, while the female pulse is at the lower gate. Thus, the male pulse is consistently weak at the wrist, whereas the female pulse is consistently strong; this is their nature.

    [Huá Shòu said: This relates to the origins of living beings, concerning the duality of male and female. The Jì family stated: At the beginning of life, everything originates from the zi, which is the source of all things. From zi, if we proceed left for men by thirty degrees, we arrive at sǐ; if we proceed right for women by twenty degrees, we also reach sǐ. This indicates the numerical principles of marriage between men and women. From sǐ, conception occurs: a man rotates left for ten months to be born in Yín, which is wood and yang; a woman rotates right for ten months to be born in Shēn, which is metal and yin. Xie said: Yín is wood, and wood generates fire; thus, fire arises from Yín and has an upward, fiery nature, so the male pulse is at the upper gate. Shēn is metal, and metal generates water; thus, water emerges from Shēn and flows downward, leading to the female pulse being at the lower gate. I humbly suggest that the yang body is light, clear, and ascends, in accordance with heavenly principles, thus the male pulse is at the upper gate; the yin body is heavy, turbid, and descends, in line with earthly principles, hence the female pulse is at the lower gate. This is the normal state of men and women.][55p]
    The reversal occurs when the male acquires the female pulse and the female acquires the male pulse.

    What illness is associated with this?

    Indeed, when the male acquires the female pulse, it indicates deficiency, with the ailment located within. If the pulse is left-sided, the illness is on the left; if right-sided, the illness is on the right. This is determined by the pulse. When the female acquires the male pulse, it signifies excess, with the ailment located in the extremities. If the pulse is left-sided, the illness is on the left; if right-sided, the illness is on the right. This is also determined by the pulse.

    The difficulty in understanding this says that the abnormality leads to excess or deficiency, indicating internal or external ailments.

    The twenty difficulties state: The classics mention that pulses can be hidden; what organs hide them? Indeed, this refers to the interplay of yin and yang. When the pulse is in the yin area and the yang pulse appears, it indicates yang surmounting yin; even if the pulse is occasionally deep and thin, this refers to yang hidden within yin. When the pulse is in the yang area and the yin pulse appears, it indicates yin surmounting yang; even if the pulse occasionally feels superficial and slippery, this refers to yin hidden within yang.

    As indicated, 'within' means it is present and should be so. The yin pulse is measured at the cun (inch), while the yang pulse is measured at the chi (foot). The term 'surmount' is akin to riding atop a vehicle. The term 'hidden' relates to the concealment of soldiers. 'To hide' means to store away. The Ding family states that this does not only refer to the cun as yang and the chi as yin; when considering the upper and lower contexts, the muscles above correspond to the yang area, while those below correspond to the yin area. This also connects.[56p]
    The "Double Yang" refers to madness; the "Double Yin" refers to insanity. Those who lose Yang see ghosts, while those who lose Yin become blind.

    The Twenty-First Hardship states: The classics say that when a person’s form is sick but their pulse is not, it is called life; when the pulse is sick but the form is not, it is called death. What does this mean? Indeed, if a person’s form is sick but their pulse is not, it does not mean there is nothing wrong. It refers to the breath not aligning with the pulse. This is a great principle.

    Zhou Zhongli said: Within the body, one may feel haggard, the spirit foggy, appetite lacking for food, yet the pulse corresponds with the four seasons without any extremes; this is a case of the form being sick while the pulse is not. Conversely, if the form is stable and harmonious but the pulse fluctuates between strong and weak, comes and goes erratically, appears taut yet is floating and slippery, or is deep and turbid without consistency, this indicates the pulse is not in harmony with the form, showing that the pulse is sick while the person is not.

    Zhongjing states: A person whose form is sick but pulse is not is termed internally empty, lacking vital energy; their spirit may be weary but not in pain. Conversely, a person whose pulse is sick but form is not is termed a "walking corpse," lacking royal energy; they may suddenly faint, fail to recognize others, and die prematurely.

    Xie said: According to the original text, the wording and meaning seem misaligned, possibly indicating a loss of coherence.[57p]
    The Twenty-Second Difficulty states: The classics say that there are movements in the meridians and diseases that arise. When one meridian transforms into two diseases, what is the reason? Indeed, the classics indicate that the movements refer to qi; the diseases that arise refer to blood. If the pathogen resides in qi, then qi causes the movement; if the pathogen resides in blood, then blood produces the resultant disease. Qi governs the respiration, while blood governs nourishment. If qi is stagnant and does not circulate, it indicates an initial disease of qi; if blood is obstructed and does not nourish, it indicates a subsequent disease of blood. Therefore, the movement occurs first, followed by the disease.

    [Hua Shou comments: "Respiration" refers to warmth; qi governs respiration, which means a person's true qi flows in and out, warming and evaporating between the skin and flesh. Blood governs nourishment, referring to the way a person's blood vessels moisten the muscles and bones, lubricating the joints and nourishing the organs. This term 'meridian' does not refer to mere dimensions but rather to the pathways of the twelve meridians. It is stated that within each meridian, there are indeed two diseases because they are differentiated by the presences of qi and blood. If the pathogen is in qi, then qi causes the movement; if it is in blood, then blood produces the disease. Stagnation of qi indicates a disease of qi, while stagnation of blood demonstrates a blood disease; thus, the movement occurs first and the disease arises afterward. The sequence implies that qi is external and blood is internal; when the exterior first encounters the pathogen, does the interior also follow suit and become ill? Yet, pathogens may only reside in qi or directly in blood; we cannot bind ourselves strictly to the sequence. The classics refer to the "Suwen," Chapter 10.][58p]
    The twenty-third difficulty states: The three Yin and three Yang meridians of the hands and feet can this be understood in terms of lengths? Yes. The three Yang meridians of the hands extend from the hands to the head, measuring five feet, equivalent to thirty-six inches, or three zhang; the three Yin meridians of the hands extend from the hands to the chest, measuring three feet five inches, equivalent to eighteen inches, or two zhang one foot; the three Yang meridians of the feet extend from the feet to the head, measuring eight feet, equivalent to forty-eight inches; the three Yin meridians of the feet extend from the feet to the chest, measuring six feet five inches, equivalent to thirty-six inches, or three zhang nine feet; the meridian that connects the two feet to the eyes measures seven feet five inches, equivalent to four zhang; the Governor Vessel and the Conception Vessel each measure four feet five inches, adding to nine feet. In total, the lengths of the meridians amount to sixteen zhang two feet, which is the measurement of the lengths of the twelve primary channels.[59p]
    Huashou said: This is the full text of the twenty-seven chapters of the "Ling Shu." The three yin and three yang are referred to in "Ling Shu" as six yin and six yang, making the meaning even clearer. According to the flow of the channels, the three yang of the hands run from the hands to the head, while the three yin of the hands run from the abdomen to the hands; the three yang of the feet run from the head down to the feet, and the three yin of the feet run from the feet up into the abdomen. This describes the degrees of the channels, hence they are all referred to from the perspective of the hands and feet. The two feet accompany the yin channel, which originates in the middle of the heel, naturally rising up behind the bone, going above the inner ankle, straight up, along the inner thigh into the yin, along the abdomen and into the chest, passing through the missing basin, exiting in front of the person’s welcoming point, entering the inner corner of the mouth and connecting with the inner canthus of the eye, combining with the sun channel to form the separate branch of the foot's lesser yin. The channel of the three yang of the feet stretches eight feet from the feet to the head. The "Records of Labor" also states that the human body is eight feet long, thus it is described in terms of the same body dimensions.[60p]
    There are twelve primary meridians and fifteen collateral meridians; what are their beginnings and ends? Indeed. The primary meridians circulate blood and qi, connecting yin and yang, nourishing the body. Their beginning is from the middle jiao, entering the hand taiyin and yangming; yangming enters the foot yangming and taiyin; taiyin enters the hand shaoyin and taiyang; taiyang enters the foot taiyang and shaoyin; shaoyin enters the hand xinzhu and shaoyang; shaoyang enters the foot shaoyang and jueyin; jueyin then returns to the hand taiyin. The fifteen collaterals separate from these, each deriving from their origins. Like a ring without an end, they continually irrigate one another, directing to the pulse at the wrist, thereby addressing all diseases and determining life and death.

    【Hua Shou said: "Yin" means to follow. "Yuan" means beginning. "Zhao" refers to a morning gathering for usage. This follows the measurement of the primary meridians mentioned above, inferring the pathways of the collaterals. The direct pathways are called primary, while those branching off are called collaterals.】[61p]
    The twelve channels have twelve collaterals, along with the Yang and Yin collaterals, making a total of fifteen collaterals concerning the large collateral of the spleen. Xie noted: Starting from the middle burner refers to the food entering the stomach and being stored there; its subtle essence transforms and flows into the hand Taiyin and Yangming, which successively pass on to the foot Jueyin, and then the Jueyin returns to the hand Taiyin. The fifteen collateral vessels all originate from the twelve primary channels, irrigating one another, like a boundless loop, reaching the pulse at the wrist and the Renying point, which can address all ailments and decide life and death. The Renying point at the wrist is traditionally identified with the arteries moving alongside the throat; during the Jin dynasty, Wang Shuhe defined it as the point at a division of the left hand in relation to the pulse, while the right hand division became the Qikou point, and later generations followed this. I humbly believe the reason the ancients designated Renying and Qikou is that Renying corresponds to the foot Yangming stomach channel, which receives the essence of grains and nourishes the five organs, while Qikou corresponds to the hand Taiyin lung channel, which regulates and balances the hundred vessels.[62p]
    The Classic text states: Understanding the beginning and the end, the interplay of Yin and Yang is determined. What does this mean? Indeed, the beginning and the end refer to the regularity of the pulse. At the cun (寸) location, the Ren (人) pulse connects the energies of Yin and Yang, flowing like a seamless loop, hence it is called the beginning. The end signifies the severing of the three Yin and three Yang pulses; when they are severed, death occurs, and death takes various forms, hence it is called the end.

    Hua Shou commented: According to the teachings of Xie, the "Ling Shu" (灵枢经) states in its ninth section that all methods of acupuncture conclude with the beginning and the end. Understanding the beginning and the end organizes the five organs, fixing the Yin and Yang. It also states: For those who are not ill, the pulse at the cun and Ren points responds to the four seasons; those with diminished energy will find both pulses weak and unresponsive to measurements. This section refers back to the previous mention of the cun and Ren pulses, which determines life and death across various diseases, suggesting that to grasp the beginning and end is to stabilize Yin and Yang. Essentially, the Yang meridians are determined by the Ren pulse, while the Yin meridians depend on the Qi pulse. The morning messenger signifies the harmony of Qi and blood, as tides rise according to the time, demonstrating the mutual use of Yin and Yang. The beginning is akin to the start of life, while the end represents the culmination of that life. To understand life and death, one must observe the pulse. The Qi of Yin and Yang flows into the morning messenger, like an unending loop, thus a person is free from illness; should there be any disruption in this flow, illness arises. Particularly, if the pulses of the three Yin and three Yang are severed, death is inevitable. The forms of death will be detailed in the following sections, which should be referenced accordingly.[63p]
    The Twenty-Four Difficulties states: When the three yin and three yang energies of the hands and feet have been exhausted, how can one discern what is favorable or unfavorable? Indeed, when the lesser yin energy in the feet is gone, the bones become shriveled. The lesser yin corresponds to the winter pulse, which flows quietly and warms the bone marrow; therefore, if the bone marrow is not warm, the flesh does not adhere to the bones. If bones and flesh are not close, the flesh becomes moist and recedes; when the flesh is moist and recoils, the teeth grow long and become brittle, and the hair lacks luster. The absence of luster indicates the bones die first. On the day of Wu, it becomes intense, and on the day of Ji, it dies. 【"Moist" is pronounced as "soft."】 【Shuai Shou commented: The following six sections are mostly similar to those in the tenth chapter of "Ling Shu." The essence of the kidneys manifests in hair, and its fullness resides in the bones. When the kidneys are exhausted, they can no longer nourish the bones or give vitality to the hair. "Flesh moist, receding" refers to the flesh shrinking away from the bones. Wu and Ji represent earth, and as earth conquers water, it thus dies on the day it dominates.】[64p]
    When the energy of the foot Taiyin is exhausted, the pulse does not nourish the lips. The lips are the foundation of the flesh. Without the nourishment of the pulse, the flesh becomes dry and taut; when the flesh is taut, the lips retract; when the lips retract, the flesh starts to die. On the day of Jia, it becomes severe; on the day of Yi, it dies.

    [Hua Shou says: The spleen's manifestation is in the lips and the four whites, and its substance is in the flesh. When the spleen is exhausted, the flesh becomes taut and the lips retract. The taut flesh means that the muscles are not smooth and moist but rather tense (月真).]

    When the energy of the foot Jueyin is exhausted, the tendons contract, pulling the ovary and curling the tongue. Jueyin pertains to the liver vessel. The liver is the gathering of the tendons. The tendons are grouped in the genital organs and connect to the root of the tongue. Thus, when the pulse does not nourish, the tendons contract tightly, pulling the ovary and the tongue. Hence, the tongue curls and the ovary shrinks, signifying that this tendon is dying first. On the day of Geng, it becomes severe; on the day of Xin, it dies.

    [Hua Shou says: The liver is the vessel of gathering; its manifestation is in the nails, and its substance is in the tendons. The tendons are grouped in the genital organs and connect to the root of the tongue. When the liver is exhausted, the tendons contract, pulling the ovary and the tongue. Wang Chong in "Lunheng" states: For those experiencing illness on the days of Jia and Yi, the periods of life and death will always occur on the day of Geng Shen.][65p]
    When the Hand Taiyin energy is exhausted, the skin and hair become scorched. Taiyin refers to the lungs, which circulate energy and warm the skin and hair. If energy fails to nourish, the skin and hair scorch; if the skin and hair scorch, bodily fluids are depleted. When bodily fluids are depleted, the skin and joints suffer damage; when the skin and joints are damaged, the skin dries and the hair falls out, leading to the death of hair. On a Bing day, it is profound, and on a Ding day, it dies.

    [Hua Shou said: The lungs are the root of qi; their manifestation is in the hair, and their essence is in the skin. When the lungs are exhausted, the skin and hair scorch, and bodily fluids are lost, resulting in joint damage, as all fluids converge at the joints.]

    When the Hand Shaoyin energy is exhausted, the pulse does not flow; when the pulse does not flow, the blood does not circulate; when the blood does not circulate, the complexion fades, resulting in a face as black as soot, indicating the death of blood first. On a Ren day, it is profound, and on a Gui day, it dies.

    [Hua Shou said: The heart governs the pulse. Its nourishment is color, its manifestation is on the face, and its essence resides in the blood vessels. When the heart is exhausted, the pulse does not flow, the blood does not circulate, and the complexion fades.]

    When the energies of all three Yin are exhausted, the eyes become dizzy and turn away, and if they close, it is a sign of lost will; when will is lost, it indicates the death of intention, leading to the closing of the eyes.

    [Hua Shou said: The three Yin are referred to in terms of the pathways of the hands and feet. The "Lingshu" mentions that when all five Yin energies are exhausted, this also pertains to the Hand Jueyin and Hand Shaoyin, converging in the heart vessel. Dizziness and closing of the eyes, referred to as the loss of Yin, lead to blindness, indicating severity. Thus, when the eyes close, the will is lost, signifying the death of intention.]

    [The Chen family of Siming said: When the Yin energies of all five viscera are exhausted, the will is lost internally, which prevents vital energy from reaching the eyes, leading to an inability to see people and ultimately death.][66p]
    When the six yang energies are completely exhausted, yin and yang separate; when yin and yang separate, the pores leak, leading to a cessation of sweat that emerges large like a string of pearls, turning out but not flowing. This is when the vital energy first dies. If predicted in the morning, death occurs in the evening; if predicted in the evening, death occurs in the morning.

    [Hua Shou states: When sweat emerges but does not flow, this is due to the failure of yang.]

    [Chen's commentary suggests: When the yang energies of the six fu organs are completely exhausted, the vital energies scatter outward, thus the fluids escape and lead to death.]

    The twenty-fifth difficulty states: There are twelve meridians, five viscera, six hollow organs, and eleven channels. What is this one channel? It is the channel of the hand shao yin (lesser yin) and the heart's controlling collateral. The heart's governing function is linked with the san jiao (triple burner) as they are interrelated in name but not in form, hence it is said that there are twelve meridians.

    [Hua Shou explains: This section of questions and answers indicates that the five viscera and six hollow organs correspond to the yin and yang of the hands and feet, but there are only eleven channels. One of them is considered as one channel due to the hand shao yin and the heart's governing function being distinct channels. The heart's controlling function and the san jiao are interrelated in name but not in form, constituting this one channel along with the five viscera and six hollow organs, making a total of twelve channels.]

    Xie states: The "Nanjing" discusses the hand shao yin, heart governing, and san jiao over eight chapters. The thirty-first difficulty elaborates on the beginnings and ends of the san jiao meridian. The thirty-seventh difficulty mentions that there are two kidneys, the left is the kidney and the right is the ming men (gate of life), initially not distinguishing between the left and right kidneys in the pulse of the two hands.[67p]
    The thirty-eighth difficulty in articulating the Sanjiao (Triple Warmer) pertains to the differentiation of the original energy, which governs all energies, further emphasizing its name yet formless nature. The thirty-ninth difficulty in discussing the Mingmen (Gate of Life) refers to the place where spirit resides; in men, it stores essence, while in women, it connects to the womb, and this energy communicates with the kidneys. It is also stated that although there are six fu organs, there are actually five, and the Sanjiao is considered one of them. In the eight difficulties, as well as in the sixty-second and sixty-sixth chapters, it discusses the movement of energy within the kidneys, which is fundamental to human life and the root of the twelve meridians. This is called the original energy, and thus the Sanjiao serves as a vessel for this original energy. By understanding this text and examining their relationships, one can see how the Sanjiao fits into the definition of the six fu organs. It is solely because it has a name yet remains formless that it can align with the hand heart meridian. The heart rules the hand Jueyin, and its channel begins in the chest and ends at the tip of the little finger. In contrast, the hand Shaoyin begins in the heart and ends at the inner side of the little finger. Therefore, the hand Shaoyin and the heart each represent a distinct channel. Someone might ask, why does the hand Jueyin meridian refer to the heart and also to the heart protector? The answer is: the sovereign fire is named, while the ministerial fire is positioned.[68p]
    The hand's yin aspect governs the heart's fire in action, thus it is called the heart's center; in terms of channels, it is called the pericardium. One channel has two names, both refer to the heart fire. Yu Shu states: Various schools say the gate of life is the heart fire, related to the sanjiao (triple warmer) in its inner and outer relationships. However, in the "Nan Jing," it only refers to the heart center and the sanjiao without mentioning the gate of life in relation to the sanjiao.

    The left wrist corresponds to fire, the right to metal; the left gate corresponds to wood, the right to earth; the left inch corresponds to water, the right to fire. The placement and meaning of these are evidently clear! According to Yu’s view, the heart center and sanjiao are interrelated and govern the action of the heart fire. The thirty-six difficult questions mention that the energy of the gate of life connects with the kidneys, suggesting it is not separate from the kidneys. Is this not referred to as the "trigram of water"? The heart center represents a position of fire, while the gate of life expresses a shared energy of water.

    The gate of life cannot be deemed the heart fire, and it is also clear that the sanjiao does not associate with the gate of life.[69p]
    The discussion of the Yu school is indeed profound! The reason various schools are confused and indecisive is likely due to their misunderstanding of the "True Words of the Golden Coffer," where Wang's annotations cite the "Rectification Theory" indicating that the San Jiao (Triple Warmer) is named yet formless, connecting the Heart Master above and the Right Kidney below, which leads to the concept of the San Jiao relating to the Life Gate.

    The organs of a person have both Yin and Yang, and are respectively paired; how could there be a theory of one channel pairing with two? The notion that it connects with the Heart Master above truly implies a relationship of exterior and interior; the connection with the Right Kidney below refers to the San Jiao as the distinct envoy of Original Qi. Understanding this clarifies that the Life Gate connects with the Kidney and that there cannot be dual pairing for the San Jiao. Hence, the various claims can be discerned and made clear without confusion.

    Regarding pulse diagnosis, the Hand Jueyin (Liver) Fire resides at the right wrist, and the San Jiao is the same. Since the Life Gate connects with the Kidney, it should be at the left wrist. Yet, Xie states in the "Pulse Classic" that the Hand Jueyin is at the same location as the Hand Shaoyin (Heart) pulse; the San Jiao pulse appears at the inch, is evident in the pass, and links with the Kidney at the lower Jiao. Previously, it was stated that the left and right Kidneys should not divide the pulses of the hands and feet, so how should the right wrist be examined according to what the "Pulse Classic" states?[70p]
    The twenty-sixth difficulty states: The classics mention twelve channels and fifteen collaterals. What are the three additional collaterals? There are the Yang collaterals, the Yin collaterals, and the Great Collateral of the Spleen. The Yang collaterals refer to the channels of Yang Qi. The Yin collaterals refer to the channels of Yin Qi. Therefore, there are fifteen collaterals.

    [Hua Shou said: The straight paths are called channels, while the branches are called collaterals. The channels are like the main flow of the rivers, while the collaterals are like tributaries. Each channel has a collateral: the twelve channels have twelve collaterals. For example, the Hand Taiyin channel is associated with the Lung collateral and the Large Intestine, while the Hand Yangming channel is associated with the Large Intestine and the Lung. Now, when saying there are fifteen collaterals, it refers to the Yang collaterals, Yin collaterals, and the Great Collateral of the Spleen. The Yang and Yin collaterals are discussed in the twenty-eighth difficulty. The term "collaterals" indicates that the extraordinary channels do not adhere strictly to the twelve channels, and they may simply be referred to as collaterals. The Great Collateral of the Spleen, called Da Bao, emerges three inches below the chest and spreads across the lateral sides, responding to the influence of ancestral Qi.]

    [The Chen family of Siming said: The Yang collaterals encompass all Yang collaterals; the Yin collaterals encompass all Yin collaterals; the Great Collateral of the Spleen, further, governs both Yin and Yang collaterals, just as the Spleen can nourish the five organs.][71p]
    The twenty-seventh difficulty states: The pulse has eight extraordinary vessels, which are not confined to the twelve regular channels; why is this? There are the Yang Wei, Yin Wei, Yang Qiao, Yin Qiao, Chong, Du, Ren, and Dai vessels. All these eight vessels are not bound by the channels, hence they are called the eight extraordinary vessels.

    [Hua Shou states: The pulse has both extraordinary and regular. The twelve channels are the regular pulses. The eight extraordinary vessels are thus not bound by the twelve standard channels, hence they are called extraordinary. "Extraordinary" in relation to "regular" is similar to how military strategies differentiate between extraordinary and regular tactics.]

    [Yu says: "Extraordinary" refers to the concept of the unexpected, meaning these eight vessels do not link to the regular channels of yin and yang, lacking mutual correspondence, pursuing their distinct paths, thus called extraordinary vessels. Among these eight vessels, the Du vessel governs the back, the Ren vessel governs the front, the Chong vessel is known as the sea of all yang, the Yin and Yang Wei provide connection throughout the body, and the Dai vessel restrains like a belt; the Yang Qiao is associated with the differentiation of the sun, while the Yin Qiao is fundamentally a distinction of the lesser yin.][72p]
    There are twelve channels and fifteen networks, totaling twenty-seven energies that follow one another up and down; why should they alone not be bound to the channels? Indeed. The sage designs canals and watercourses to facilitate water flow, preparing for unexpected events. When heaven rains down and the canals overflow, at that moment, mischief arises, and the sage cannot design again. At this point, the networks are overflowing, and the channels cannot be bound anymore.

    [Hua Shou said: The flow of the channels has its regular measure, but the Eight Extraordinary Vessels cannot follow one another; hence the sage's design of canals serves as a metaphor. It shows that when the networks overflow, the channels cannot be restrained, resulting in these extraordinary vessels. So, do the extraordinary vessels arise from the overflow of the networks? Some say: the term "networks" points specifically to the extraordinary vessels, which are not confined to the channels, and may rightly be called networks.]

    [This section highlights the names of the Eight Vessels and the meaning of why they are considered extraordinary.][73p]
    The twenty-eighth difficulty states: The eight extraordinary vessels, which do not conform to the twelve primary channels, where do they originate and how are they connected?

    Indeed. The Governing Vessel originates at the lower back's point, travels along the spine, ascends to the Wind Palace, and enters the brain. The Conception Vessel begins below the central point, rises at the base of the hairline, goes through the abdomen, ascends to the Sea of Qi, and reaches the throat. The Penetrating Vessel starts at the Qi Chong, follows the stands of the Yangming channel, rises above the navel, and spreads within the chest. The Belt Vessel originates at the lateral costal region, wrapping around the body. The Yang Heel Vessel begins at the center of the heel, traverses along the outer ankle, and enters the Wind Pool. The Yin Heel Vessel also begins at the heel's center, travels up the inner ankle to the throat, and intersects with the Penetrating Vessel. The Yang and Yin Linking Vessels connect throughout the body, accommodating and allowing the flow to nourish and irrigate the various channels.[74p]
    Thus, the Yang vessels arise from the convergence of various Yang channels, while the Yin vessels emerge from the intersections of various Yin channels. It is like a sage who designs ditches; when the ditches overflow, they flow into deep lakes, thus the sage cannot contain the flow. In humans, the vessels flourish but do not encircle, hence the twelve channels also cannot be contained. When they receive pathogenic energy, they accumulate and can lead to swelling and heat, resulting in needling and moxibustion.

    [Huashou comments: "Ji" is noted as "xi" in the "Pulse Canon." "Du" signifies "capital," representing the sea of Yang vessels, where all Yang vessels converge. The vessels rise from the lower extreme points, through the perineum and continue along the spine to the Dazhui point, intersecting with the three Yang vessels of the hands and feet, then ascending to the Yumen point where they connect with the Yangwei vessel, reaching the Baihui point where they meet the Taiyang channel, and further up to the nasal column at the Renzhong point where they connect with the Yangming channel. The Ren vessel arises from below the Zhongji point at the pubic bone. The Ren vessel represents nurturing, serving as the foundation for human life.][75p]
    The Chong vessel originates at the Qichong point, spreads through the chest, and is known as the sea of yin vessels. The Inner Canon states it is associated with the lesser yin meridians of the feet. The Chong vessel travels through the pylorus, connecting to the gut and moving upwards, all of which are lesser yin, aligning with the Inner Canon. The Du, Ren, and Chong vessels all begin at the perineum, indicating they share a single source that branches into three paths. The Dai vessel starts one inch and eight tenths below the lateral costal region and wraps around the body like a belt. The Yang Qiao vessel originates from the midpoint of the heel at the Shenmai point and flows around the outer ankle. The Yin Qiao vessel also begins at the heel at the Zhaohai point and flows around the inner ankle. The term "Qiao" signifies agility. Since both vessels originate from the foot, they embody the idea of quickness and transcendence. The Yang Wei and Yin Wei vessels connect throughout the body, serving as the supportive framework for yin and yang.[76p]
    The Yangwei channel is initiated at the Yang convergence, separate from the Golden Gate, where it intersects with Yang. It connects with the hands and feet of the Sun channel at the shoulder point, and meets the Sun channels of the hands and feet at Tianliao and Jianjing, respectively. It also intersects with the Sun channel of the feet at Yangbai, extending upwards to Shen, Linqi, Zhengying, and Naokong, and downwards to Fengchi, converging with the Governing Vessel at Fengfu and Yamen. This is the origin of the Yangwei channel at the convergence of the various Yang channels.

    The acuity of the Yinwei channel is referred to as Zhubin, which intersects with the foot Taiyin at Funa and Dahu, and also connects with the foot Taiyin and Jueyin at Fush and Qimen, as well as with Renmai at Tiantu and Lianquan. This indicates the origin of the Yinwei from the convergence of the various Yin channels.

    Excess and retention that cannot circulate and irrigate the twelve channels must refer to the twelve characters, which should fit within the twelve channels yet cannot be confined to them, allowing for unfettered interaction. The reception of pathogenic energies, as noted in the twelve characters, has been deemed as potentially lacking text above and below in the original writings by the Xie family, yet concerning the meridians, there appears to be no such, raising suspicions about textual additions. Others suggest that it should be placed under the thirty-seven difficult points, unable to fulfill its mandate and resulting in death, since the pathogenic influences pertain to the six fu organs.[77p]
    The Twenty-Ninth Difficulty states: What are the ailments of the extraordinary channels? Indeed. Yang Wei is connected in the Yang, and Yin Wei is connected in the Yin. If Yin and Yang cannot support each other, then one will feel lost and aimless, unable to gather oneself. When Yang Wei is ailing, there is suffering from cold and heat. When Yin Wei is ailing, there is suffering from heart pain. When Yin Qiao is ailing, Yang is slow while Yin is urgent. When Yang Qiao is ailing, Yin is slow while Yang is urgent. When Chong is ailing, there is reversed qi and internal urgency. When Du is ailing, the spine is rigid and there is a sensation of coldness. When Ren is ailing, there is internal distress; for men, it manifests as seven kinds of hernias, and for women, it manifests as accumulations. When Dai is ailing, there is abdominal fullness, and the waist feels as if submerged in water. This describes the ailments of the eight extraordinary vessels. [The phrase "when Yang Wei is ailing" mentions the total categories of deficiencies and errors.] [Hua Shou said: This speaks of the diseases of the extraordinary channels.][78p]
    If Yin cannot be maintained within Yin, then one will feel lost and disheartened. If Yang cannot be maintained within Yang, then the energies cannot self-regulate. Yang governs actions in the realm of Yang and signifies protection; protection represents Qi, and Qi resides on the surface, hence the suffering from extreme cold and heat. Yin governs actions in the realm of Yin and signifies nourishment; nourishment represents blood, which belongs to the heart, thus leading to heart pain.

    When the pulse is affected in Yang, it manifests as urgency; when affected in Yin, it also shows urgency. Those who are ill feel anxious, while those who are not recover on their own. The Chong vessel runs from the lower abdomen to the throat, hence the feeling of rebellious Qi and urgency. The Du vessel runs along the back, leading to rigidity and extremities feeling cold. The Ren vessel begins at the gate of the womb and travels through the abdomen, hence the internal suffering from stagnation, with men experiencing seven hernias and women suffering from masses.

    If one rotates around it, the symptoms present themselves accordingly. "Lack of strength" is a notable appearance. Each condition is described based on the corresponding meridians. From the twenty-seven difficulties onward, the meanings are interconnected, and it is advisable to explore them thoroughly.[79p]
    The "Thirty Difficulties" states: Is the function of the nourishing qi always accompanied by the protective qi? Indeed. The classics mention that food enters the stomach, then is transmitted to the five organs and six bowels; all five organs and six bowels receive qi. The pure essence is for nourishment, and the turbid essence is for protection. Nourishing qi circulates within the meridians, while protective qi flows outside them, nourishing ceaselessly, reaching fifty and then returning to great harmony, where yin and yang interlink, like a seamless circle. Hence, it is known that nourishment and protection accompany each other.

    [Hua Shou said: This passage aligns with the words of the "Spiritual Pivot," chapter eighteen. While food enters the stomach and is transmitted to the five organs and six bowels, the “Spiritual Pivot” states that it enters the lungs, with the five organs and six bowels all receiving qi, which is somewhat different. All receive the essence of qi, referring to the qi from water and grain. The return to great harmony at fifty is discussed in one of the difficulties. The Chen family of Siming said: Nourishment is yin, its movement is inherently slow; protection is yang, its movement is inherently fast. However, the pure is smooth and effective, while the turbid is vigorous and forceful; neither is sluggish in form. Thus, when protective qi moves outside, nourishing qi follows within, indicating their movement is consistently accompanied, encompassing their measure.

    The Wang family of HunNan said: The pure is the essence of the body, it is yang, it is fire; one aspect of yin descends from the center, thus, after noon, one yin is born, this refers to the heart producing blood, therefore it is said that the pure qi is for nourishment. [The clear of heaven does not descend, the turbid of earth can descend through the six yin, driving it downward. The term "clear qi" is addressed in relation to the essence of separation.][80p]
    The turbid represents the lower aspect, the yin, the water. Within the depths, one yang arises, hence when the offspring of yang is born, it is the vital energy of the kidney, therefore it is said that turbid qi serves as the guardian.

    The earth's turbidity does not ascend; the clarity of the earth can rise to form the six yangs, elevating and letting them ascend. When we speak of turbid qi, it refers to the overall essence of the depths.

    The classics say: the earth's qi rises to form clouds, while the air's qi descends to create rain; rain arises from the earth's qi, and clouds emerge from the heavens' qi—this is what it refers to.

    I humbly suggest that in terms of application, pure qi represents the essence, being the pure part within the turbid; while turbid qi, serving as the guardian, is the turbid part within the pure. Speaking of essence, the use of the pure does not separate from the essence of the turbid, and the use of the turbid does not separate from the essence of the pure. Therefore, it is also valid to say that pure qi represents the essence and turbid qi serves as the guardian, or to say that essence, turbidity, guardian, and purity can be interchangeable.[81p]
    Ji also said: "The Suwen states that 'the nutritive essence is the refined energy of food and water, which is clear; the protective energy is the coarse energy of food and water, which is turbid.' When the refined energy enters the channels, it becomes turbid; when the coarse energy moves outside the channels, it is clear. Someone asked about the Thirty-Two Difficulties: 'Blood is for the nutritive essence, and qi is for the protective energy. Why is both the nutritive and protective essence described in terms of qi?' The answer is: 'The classics state that the nutritive essence is the refined energy of food and water, and the protective energy is the coarse energy of food and water. It further states that the clear energy is for the nutritive essence, while the turbid energy is for the protective essence. Generally speaking, both the nutritive and protective essence are functions of the energy from food and water, so it is appropriate to refer to them using the term qi. However, when analyzed in detail, the nutritive essence refers to blood and the protective essence to qi, which have their distinct roles. Therefore, the nutritive essence flows within the channels, while the protective essence circulates outside the channels, similar to water in rivers and lakes or wind and clouds in the vast emptiness."[82p]
    The Difficulties of Bian Que: Volume on the Lower Jiao

    Difficulty Thirty-One: What is the nature of the San Jiao (Three Jiao)? How does it originate and how does it conclude? Where does its treatment normally take place? Can this be elucidated? Yes. The San Jiao is the pathway of food and fluid, where Qi begins and ends. The Upper Jiao is located beneath the heart, above the diaphragm, within the stomach, governing internal matters without release, its treatment is in the Zhongji (central vessel), one and a half inches below the Xuanfu (suspended hall) between the two breasts. The Middle Jiao is in the middle of the stomach, neither ascending nor descending, governing the fermentation of food and fluid, its treatment lies beside the navel. The Lower Jiao is at the entrance of the bladder, governing the differentiation of clear and turbid, promoting outflow rather than influx to facilitate the pathway, its treatment is one inch below the navel. Thus, it is called the Three Jiao, whose cavities are in the pathways of Qi.

    [Slightly different interpretation: The term "pathway" may also be written as "Chong".]

    [Hua Shou stated: The organs and viscera of the human body possess form and shape, have nature and life, such as the liver obtaining Qi from wood and generating from water, and the heart obtaining Qi from fire and generating from wood, and this applies universally. Only the San Jiao is formless, and what it receives and generates is merely the Yuan Qi (original Qi) and the stomach Qi, hence it is described as the pathway of food and fluid, where Qi begins and ends. The treatment of the Upper Jiao is in the Zhongji, the treatment of the Middle Jiao is at the Tianshu point beside the navel, and the treatment of the Lower Jiao is at the Yinjiao point one inch below the navel. “Treatment” is akin to “govern”, similar to the governance of prefectures and counties, referring to the areas of the San Jiao. Some say to pronounce 'treatment' with a level tone, suggesting that when there is illness in the San Jiao, each section should be treated accordingly, implying needling methods. The San Jiao represents the fire of the heart; fire can ferment and mature all things, and 'Jiao' relates to the essence of fermentation, hence the naming and meaning may derive from this.][83p]
    The eighteenth chapter of the "Spiritual Pivot" states: The upper focus emerges from the mouth of the stomach, extends above the throat, passes through the diaphragm, spreads in the chest, travels to the armpit, follows the pathway of the Taiyin channel, and returns to the Yangming channel at the sublingual area under the foot of Yangming, consistently traveling in the Yang at twenty-five degrees, and in the Yin also at twenty-five degrees, thus completing a circuit. Hence, at fifty degrees, it converges again at the hand of Taiyin. The middle focus is also adjacent to the stomach's entrance; after the emergence from the upper focus, it receives the air, processes the dregs, steams the fluid, transforms its essence, and ascends into the lung meridian, being refined into blood to nourish the body. Nothing is more precious than this, so it uniquely circulates through the meridian pathways, and is referred to as Yingqi (Nutritive Qi). The lower focus differs by connecting the small intestine to the bladder, seeping into it.[84p]
    Thus, the water and grain are constantly combined in the stomach, transforming into dregs that descend together into the large and small intestines to form the lower jiao. They seep down, mixing and separating the juices, following the lower jiao to penetrate the bladder. Xie states: By examining the text of the "Lingshu," it becomes evident that the three jiaos have names but no tangible form. Ancient scholar Yuan says: The so-called three jiaos reside within the fatty tissues of the diaphragm, in the spaces between the five organs and six bowels, where water and grain flow and transform. Their qi merges within, steaming and affecting the diaphragm, spreading to the skin and flesh, circulating to all sides, referred to as upper, middle, and lower, each named according to its respective region, essentially being agents of the original qi. Therefore, although they lack physical form, they take their names from the inner and outer forms; and although they lack substantiality, they occupy positions by combining inner and outer realities. I foolishly note that the phrase regarding their location in the channels seems to be erroneous or extended. The three jiaos naturally belong to the various organs, with their channels being associated with the hand's lesser yang, and connected to the hand's heart, each having its own therapeutic locale, and should not be considered as additional organs.[85p]
    The Thirty-Second Difficulty states: The five organs are equal, yet the heart and lungs uniquely reside above the diaphragm. Why is this? Indeed. The heart represents blood, while the lungs represent qi; blood is for nourishment, and qi is for defense, mutually supporting each other up and down, termed nourishment and defense. They circulate through the meridians, nourishing from without, hence the heart and lungs are situated above the diaphragm.

    [Hua Shou said: The nourishing function of the heart and the defensive function of the lungs circulate through the meridians and nourish from without, much like the celestial way operating above. The diaphragm acts as a barrier. In humans, there is a membrane beneath the heart, connected with the spine and ribs, which blocks turbid qi from rising and affecting the heart and lungs.]

    [Chen of Siming said: This specifically refers to their positional hierarchy. If discussing the virtues of the five organs, there is more to say. Since the heart and lungs are capable of generating life through blood and qi, they are the parents of the body; naturally, given the honor of parents, they reside above. The 'Neijing' states: Above the diaphragm lies the central region containing the parents. This is what is meant.][86p]
    The thirty-third difficulty states: The liver is likened to wood, and the lungs to metal; when the liver receives water, it sinks, while wood floats; when the lungs receive water, they float, while metal sinks. What does this mean? Indeed, the liver is not purely wood. It corresponds to the yang aspect, and the yin aspect is related to the soft nature. It speaks broadly of yin and yang, and more specifically of husband and wife, releasing its subtle yang while absorbing subtle yin energy. Its essence is in pleasure and the path of yin, hence causing the liver to sink when it receives water.

    The lungs are not purely metal either; they correspond to the yin aspect. It speaks broadly of yin and yang, and more specifically of husband and wife, releasing its subtle yin to join with fire. Its essence is in pleasure and the path of yang, hence causing the lungs to float when they receive water.

    Why do the lungs settle down again while the liver floats, and why does the liver settle again while the lungs float? Therefore, it is understood that the yin corresponds to the yang aspect, as does the liver to the metal element.

    [Huashou comments: The Chen family from Siming states that the liver corresponds to the wood element, reflecting the sounds of the angles, which are heavy and turbid. When analyzed, it can be seen that the yang aspect corresponds to wood's yang aspect, while the yin aspect corresponds to wood's yin aspect; together they are all yang.][87p]
    Due to its association with the lesser yang and its position in the yin part of the human body, it is recognized as the yang within yin. Yang must necessarily unite with yin; the yin and yang of jia and yi are inherently paired, and yi connects with geng, embodying the way of hardness and softness. Yi harmonizes with the subtle yang of jia and counteracts the joy of metal, thus receiving the subtle yin energy of geng, forming a marital relationship. The nature of wood is inherently buoyant; as it receives the energy of metal and inhabits the path of yin, it thus acquires water and sinks. Upon maturity, the received energy of metal departs, yi returns to jia, and the original nature of wood naturally becomes buoyant again. The lungs belong to geng and xin metal, responding to the sound of shang and embodying lightness and clarity. Analyzing it, geng represents the yang of metal, while xin represents the yin of metal; combined, they are both yin. Since it is associated with the greater yin and located in the yang part of the human body, it is considered yin within yang. Yin must necessarily unite with yang; the yin and yang of geng and xin are inherently paired, and xin connects with bing, reflecting the way of hardness and softness. Xin harmonizes with the subtle yin of geng, thus counteracting the joy of fire, and forms a marital relationship with the yang of bing fire. The nature of metal is fundamentally heavy; as it receives the energy of fire and rises, it occupies the path of yang, thus acquiring water and floating.[88p]
    When it is sufficiently matured, the fire’s essence is removed, and the yin wood (乙) returns to the yang metal (庚), causing the essence of metal to naturally sink. The ancient scholar Yuan said: the liver represents the yin wood (乙), and the lungs represent the yin metal (辛), corresponding to their respective sounds. The combination of 乙 and 庚, and that of 丙 and 辛, resembles a marital relationship. Thus, they temporarily relinquish their inherent natures to follow the influences of their partners' essences, demonstrating the interaction of yin and yang. Moreover, the liver is located below the diaphragm, while the lungs reside above; the upper is yang and the lower is yin. Their pathways express differentiation, causing wood to float and reflect the sinking nature of metal, while metal sinks and reflects the upward movement of fire. Everything, when reaching its extreme, will reverse, and when it undergoes transformation and change, it returns to its origin and its true nature. Hence, when the liver and lungs mature, they each manifest the inherent nature of wood and metal. The Ji school states: the liver is the yang within yin, having a predominant yin quality and does not conform to wood, thus it sinks with water. The lungs are the yin within yang, having a predominant yang quality and do not conform to metal, thus they float with water. This refers to their larger aspects. However, speaking of their smaller aspects, the relationships of 乙, 庚, 丙, and 辛 represent the path of marital dynamics.[89p]
    When they become熟 (ripe) and the processes of settling and floating reverse, each returns to its origin, hence they reveal their true nature. The Zhou school says: the liver stores blood, which is the essence of Yin; having more blood and less Qi, its body becomes congealed and obstructed. Although there are meridians and internal pathways, they cannot compare to the exquisite emptiness, therefore it sinks when water is present. When熟, the moist and nourishing aspect transitions to dryness; the congealed and obstructed transforms into an unobstructed void, suitable for floating. The lungs govern Qi, which is Yang; having more Qi and less blood, its body hangs down and is light, with openings and passages that are exquisite; the meridians branch out, hence it floats when water is present. When熟, the body tightens and contracts; the openings become obstructed and solid; those that were lightly expansive transform into tightness, which is suitable for sinking. This natural principle aligns with the subtle transformations of the five elements. Xie says: this reasoning derives from the nature of things. I humbly assert that the liver is Yang, a form of Yang within Yin; since Yin is more abundant, it is called微阳 (subtle Yang), residing below and following the Yin path. The lung is Yin, a form of Yin within Yang; since Yang is more abundant, it is called微阴 (subtle Yin), residing above and following the Yang path. When熟, it loses all delight and returns to its essence, why is this? Because when things become熟, the mingling of energies disperses.[90p]
    The Thirty-Fourth Difficulties states: The five organs each have their own sounds, colors, odors, and tastes, which can all be understood, correct? Yes. The Ten Transformations says: The liver is green in color, has a rancid smell, a sour taste, a sound like a call, and its fluid is tears. The heart is red in color, has a burnt smell, a bitter taste, a sound like speech, and its fluid is sweat. The spleen is yellow in color, has a fragrant smell, a sweet taste, a sound like singing, and its fluid is saliva. The lungs are white in color, have a fishy smell, a spicy taste, a sound like crying, and its fluid is mucus. The kidneys are black in color, have a rotten smell, a salty taste, a sound like groaning, and its fluid is spittle. These are the sounds, colors, odors, and tastes of the five organs.

    [Hua Shou commented: This describes the functions of the five organs; the terms sound, color, odor, and taste are lacking the word for fluid. The liver is green, has a rancid smell, corresponds to wood; the call signifies the emission of wood; the sour taste is derived from the bending and straightening as it becomes sour; the fluid of tears relates to the eyes.][91p]
    The heart is red, with a burnt smell, and it transforms through fire; speaking raises the fire; its taste is bitter, as heat produces bitterness; its fluid is sweat, which is related to blood, as sweat pertains to blood. The spleen is yellow with a fragrant smell, and it transforms through earth; singing is the softening of earth, and it is said that the spleen's spirit enjoys music, thus its sound is primarily song; its taste is sweet, as agriculture produces sweetness; its fluid is saliva, which connects to the mouth. The lungs are white, with a fishy smell, and they transform through metal; crying is the sorrow of metal; its taste is spicy, formed from the skin; its fluid is mucus, which connects to the nose. The kidneys are black, with a rotten smell, and they transform through water; groaning resembles the sound of water; its taste is salty, as moisture creates saltiness; its fluid is spittle, related to water.

    The Chen family of Siming states: the kidneys are located far away; if they do not extend, the energy cannot reach the breath, hence the sounds of groans come from the kidneys. However, the lungs govern sound, the liver governs color, the heart governs smell, the spleen governs taste, and the kidneys govern fluids. The five organs are interconnected and encompass each other, thus it is said there are ten transformations.[92p]
    The five organs have seven spirits; what does each contain? Indeed. The organs are the dwelling places of the spirit and energy of a person. Therefore, the liver contains the soul, the lungs contain the body, the heart contains the spirit, the spleen contains intention and wisdom, and the kidneys contain essence and will.

    [Huashou said: The organs are places of storage; the spirit and energy of a person are contained within. The soul is the assistant of clarity; it follows the spirit and is called the soul. The body is the complement of essence; it enters and exits in conjunction with essence and is called the body. The spirit is the transformation of essence; when two essences are thin together, it is called spirit. The spleen governs thinking, thus storing intention and wisdom. The kidneys are the officials of strength, facilitating skill, thus they store essence and will. This discussion pertains to the functions of the five organs regarding their spirits; thus the five functions manifest outwardly while the seven spirits are contained inwardly.]

    The thirty-fifth difficulty states: The five organs each have their own functions, and the viscera are all similar, yet the heart and lungs are uniquely distant from the large and small intestines. Why is this so? Indeed. The classics state that the heart nourishes the lungs and circulates yang energy; hence, it is positioned above. The large and small intestines transmit yin energy and are positioned below; thus they are distanced from each other.

    [Huashou said: The heart nourishes the lungs, circulates yang energy, and resides above; the large and small intestines transmit yin energy and reside below, hence the necessity of their distance.]

    Furthermore, all the viscera are yang; being places of purity, why are the large intestine, small intestine, stomach, and bladder all subject to impurity?

    [Huashou said: If all the viscera are yang, they should be pure places. Why then do the large intestine, small intestine, stomach, and bladder all receive impurities?][93p]
    Indeed. To refer to the various organs as such is incorrect. The classics say that the small intestine is the organ of reception; the large intestine is the organ of transmission and excretion; the gallbladder is the organ of purification; the stomach is the organ of food and drink; the bladder is the organ of fluids. Since one organ cannot have two names, it is clear that this is not the case. The small intestine is the organ of the heart, the large intestine is the organ of the lungs, the gallbladder is the organ of the liver, the stomach is the organ of the spleen, and the bladder is the organ of the kidneys.

    [Hua Shou said: To call the organs places of purity is incorrect. Now, the large intestine, small intestine, stomach, and bladder each have their own roles, therefore they are not merely places of yang purity. Each is an organ of the five viscera, it is indeed inappropriate to give them two names. The essence of the organs is yang, but their function is yin, which is what the classics refer to when they say the turbid yin returns to the six organs. It is stated that all organs are yang, and the place of purity is solely the gallbladder.]

    The small intestine is called the red intestine, the large intestine is called the white intestine, the gallbladder is called the green intestine, the stomach is called the yellow intestine, and the bladder is called the black intestine, governing the lower focus.

    [Hua Shou said: This differentiates the five viscera by their colors, and all are referred to by the term "intestines." The phrase regarding the lower focus pertains to the bladder, which is responsible for separating the clear from the turbid.][94p]
    The thirty-sixth difficulty states: Each organ has one ear, yet the kidneys possess two. Why is this? Indeed, the two are not both considered kidneys; the left one is the kidney, while the right one is the Mingmen. The Mingmen is the dwelling of the spirits and the connection to the original Qi. For men, it is where essence is stored, and for women, it is where the womb is connected. Thus, it is known that the kidneys have one aspect.

    [Hua Shou commented: The kidneys have two aspects, with the left being the kidney and the right being the Mingmen. Men store essence here and receive the essences of the five organs and six bowels; women connect to the womb here, allowing them to receive essence and facilitate transformation. The original Qi refers to the moving Qi between the kidneys below the navel, the essence of life for humans, and the root of the twelve meridians. This text indicates that not both are kidneys; the thirty-ninth difficulty also states the left is the kidney and the right is the Mingmen, asserting that their Qi connects with the kidneys, demonstrating that the two aspects are essentially one. Therefore, the "Xiang family teachings" cite Sha Sui Cheng Ke Jiu, stating: "In the north, two entities are commonly paired; it is why Kan is associated with things as tortoise and snake, representing the direction of winter and north, and in the great source, it represents the unseen and the dark." The "Nan Jing" states: "Organs have one aspect, yet the kidneys alone have two," which refers to this concept.]

    [This also connects to the thirty-eighth and thirty-ninth difficulties; a thorough understanding can be derived from consulting them in order.][95p]
    The Thirty-Seventh Difficulty states: Where does the vital energy of the five organs originate? Where does it connect? Can it be explained? Indeed. The five organs are connected to the nine orifices above. Thus, the lung’s energy connects to the nose; when the nose is harmonious, one can discern aromas and odors. The liver’s energy connects to the eyes; when the eyes are harmonious, one can discern black and white. The spleen’s energy connects to the mouth; when the mouth is harmonious, one can discern the flavors of grains. The heart’s energy connects to the tongue; when the tongue is harmonious, one can discern the five tastes. The kidney’s energy connects to the ears; when the ears are harmonious, one can discern the five sounds.

    [Hua Shou says: Xie mentions that this section inquires about where the energy of the five organs originates and where it connects, but the answer only describes the connection of the five organs to the nine orifices and does not address their origin, which might indicate a missing text. It is my humble opinion that the origin of the five organs should be consistent with the explanation given in the Twenty-Third Difficulty regarding flow. The mention of the nine orifices in relation to the seven orifices in the 'Ling Shu' is the same below.][96p]
    When the five organs are not harmonious, the nine orifices are obstructed; when the six bowels are not harmonious, it leads to the formation of abscesses.

    If the pathogen resides in the six bowels, then the yang channels are not harmonious; when the yang channels are not harmonious, qi becomes stagnant, and if qi is stagnant, the yang channels become excessive. If the pathogen resides in the five organs, then the yin channels are not harmonious; when the yin channels are not harmonious, blood becomes stagnant, and if blood is stagnant, the yin channels become excessive. When yin energy is too excessive, yang energy cannot thrive, hence it is said to be inhibited. When yang energy is too excessive, yin energy cannot thrive, hence it is said to be obstructed. When both yin and yang are excessive, they cannot interact, thus it is termed as blocked obstruction. Blocked obstruction means one cannot fully live out their life and may die.

    This closely resembles the text from the "Spiritual Pivot," Chapter Seventeen. It is sometimes said that when the pathogen accumulates, it causes swelling and heat, and one should use acupuncture to dispel it, which should be seen as a conclusion to this chapter. Indeed, when the energies of yin and yang are excessively strong, it leads to blocked obstruction, which is fatal. However, if one simply suffers from the invasion of pathogens, accumulation should appropriately be treated with acupuncture. This refers to treating the conditions related to the six bowels not being harmonious and the pathogens residing therein.[97p]
    The text states that qi travels independently within the five organs and does not participate in the six bowels. Why is this so? Indeed, the path of qi is like water flowing without pause. Hence, the yin channels circulate in the five organs, while the yang channels nourish the six bowels, forming a loop with no end that is hard to track. It ends and begins again, unspilling and overflowing. The qi within a person remains warm in the organs and moist externally in the skin.

    [Hua Shou comments: This extrapolates from the previous chapter’s discussion on “nourishing.” It is similar to the seventeenth chapter of the "Lingshu." When it is said that qi travels independently in the five organs and does not nourish the six bowels, it does not mean that it does not nourish the six bowels; rather, in the yin channels it nurtures the five organs, and in the yang channels it nourishes the six bowels. The qi circulates continuously like an endless loop, thus protecting against any potential gravity or overflow, allowing the internal qi to remain warm in the organs and to be moist externally in the skin.]

    [Chen from Siming remarks: When there is evil in the bowels, the yang channels are vigorous; when there is evil in the organs, the yin channels are vigorous. If the yin channels are vigorous, it implies that the yin qi is concentrated below; if the yang channels are vigorous, then the yang qi is blocked above, but this does not lead to death. When both yin and yang are vigorous, there is both blockage and constraint, resulting in vomiting and food not being ingested, while both yin closes off, preventing bowel movements and consequently leading to death. If the qi of the organs and bowels is harmonious and nourishes one another, with no excess from the yin and no overflow from the yang, then there would be no blockage or constraint![98p]
    The thirty-eighth difficulty states: "The organs have only five, while the bowels have six; what is the reason for this?" Indeed, the reason the bowels are said to have six is because of the triple warmer. There is a distinction regarding the original qi, which governs various energies; it is named but has no form. Its channel corresponds to the Hand Shao Yang and is classified as a bowel. Thus, it is said that the bowels have six.

    [Hua Shou comments: The triple warmer governs various energies and serves as the distinct messenger of the original qi. The original qi relies on its guidance to move silently and operate within the body without interruption. The external bowel refers to its channel as the Hand Shao Yang, for the triple warmer has a channel outside but no form within; hence it is stated in detail in the sixty-sixth difficulty.][99p]
    The thirty-ninth difficulty states: The classics say there are five intestines and six organs; what does this mean? Indeed. The six intestines refer to the normally five intestines. As for the five organs, there are also six; this is because the kidneys have two organs, the left being the kidney and the right being the gate of life. The gate of life is where the spirit resides; in men, it stores essence, and in women, it is connected to the womb. Its energy communicates with the kidneys, hence it is said there are six organs. What does it mean that there are five intestines? Indeed, each of the five organs corresponds to one intestine, and the triple warmer also counts as one intestine; however, it does not belong to the five organs, thus it is said there are five intestines.

    [Hua Shou commented: In the previous section, it stated there are five organs and six intestines; this says there are five intestines and six organs because the kidneys have two. Although the left and right gates of life are distinguished, their energies are interconnected, thus they are collectively considered as the kidneys. The five intestines are understood by aligning the triple warmer with the hand's main function. When considering all sections, one can say there are five organs and six intestines, or five organs and five intestines, or six organs and six intestines.][100p]
    The "Forty Difficulties" states: The classics say the liver governs color, the heart governs odor, the spleen governs taste, the lungs govern sound, and the kidneys govern fluids. The nose is a proxy of the lungs, allowing an understanding of fragrance and odor, while the ears are a proxy of the kidneys, enabling the perception of sound. What does this mean? Indeed, the lungs represent metal in the west. Metal is generated in the hours of the snake, which corresponds to the fire of the south. Fire relates to the heart, which governs odor, hence allowing the nose to discern fragrance and odor. The kidneys represent water in the north. Water is generated in the hours of the monkey, which corresponds to metal in the west. Metal corresponds to the lungs, which govern sound, thus allowing the ears to perceive sound.

    [Huashou remarks: The Fourth Ming Chen family states that odor is governed by the heart, the nose is the orifice of the lungs, and as the heart’s vessels connect to the lungs, this gives the nose the ability to discern fragrance and odor. The ears are the orifice of the kidneys, and sound is governed by the lungs; thus, as the vessels of the kidneys connect to the lungs, this allows the ears to hear sound. I foolishly note that the perspectives of the Yue people likely arise from the principle of the generative cycle of the five elements, further exhibiting their interdependence and utility.][101p]
    The forty-first difficulty states: The liver has only two lobes; how does it respond? Indeed. The liver is associated with the east and wood, and wood represents spring. As all things begin to grow, they are still young and unattached, remaining close to the moon and not far from the sun. Therefore, it possesses dual characteristics, hence the two lobes, which correspond to the leaves of wood.

    [Hua Shou says: The Chen family of Siming notes: The interrelation of the five organs is like the way of mother and child. Thus, the kidney is the mother of the liver, belonging to the greater yin; the heart is the child of the liver, belonging to the greater yang. The position of the liver is close to the kidney and not far from the heart either. I foolishly believe that the liver’s two lobes correspond to the wood of the east, representative of spring when all things begin to grow, symbolizing the dual leaves of plants. People from Yue occasionally observe this and establish discussions around it, yet it isn’t absolute; it isn’t completely false either. When discussing the greater yin and greater yang, it need not refer strictly to the organs and seasonal phenomena, but rather that the depth of winter represents the peak of yin and early summer signifies the height of yang. Referring to them as greater yin and greater yang is not inappropriate. In general, when studying, one must be flexible and vibrant, not stagnant or muddled. The ancients referred to aligning intention with will, which signifies understanding, indeed. The latter section mentions the liver having three lobes on the left and four on the right; this mention of two lobes simply sums up the larger ones.][102p]
    The Forty-Second Difficulty states: What is the length and capacity of the human stomach and intestines in relation to the amount of food and water they can hold? Indeed, the stomach measures one foot five inches in height, five inches in diameter, and two feet six inches in length when it is curved; it can hold three pecks five liters, of which two pecks remain as food and one peck five liters is water. The small intestine is two and a half inches wide, with a diameter of seven-tenths of an inch, and measures three zhang two feet in length, holding two pecks four liters of food and six liters three-tenths of a liter. The ileum is four inches wide, one and a half inches in diameter, and two zhang one foot in length, holding one peck and seven liters half.
