The large intestine is eight inches wide, two feet five inches in diameter, and two feet eight inches in length, holding nine liters three-tenths of a liter, less one-eighth of a liter. Therefore, the total length of the stomach and intestines is five zhang eight feet four inches, with a total capacity for food and water of eight pecks seven liters six-tenths of a liter. This specifies the length and capacity of the stomach and intestines. [Huashou says: The ileum refers to the large intestine. The large intestine is a general term for the anus.][103p]
    The liver weighs two pounds and four ounces, with three lobes on the left and four on the right, totaling seven lobes; its function is to house the soul. The heart weighs twelve ounces, containing seven orifices and three hairs, filled with three measures of essence; it serves to house the spirit. The spleen weighs two pounds and three ounces, with a width of three inches and a length of five inches, possessing half a pound of fat; it functions to warm and wrap the blood of the five organs and houses intentions. The lungs weigh three pounds and three ounces, with six lobes and two ears, totaling eight lobes; their function is to house the corporeal soul. The kidneys consist of two parts, weighing one pound and one ounce; they are responsible for housing will. The gallbladder is located between the short lobes of the liver, weighing three ounces and three pennyweights, filled with three measures of essence. The stomach weighs two pounds and one ounce, is curved and flexible, with a length of two feet and six inches, a width of one foot and five inches, and a diameter of five inches; it can hold two bushels of grain and one and a half pints of water. The small intestine weighs two pounds and fourteen ounces, with a length of three zhang and two feet, a width of two and a half inches, and a diameter of slightly less than eight-tenths of an inch, making sixteen turns to the left, holding two bushels and four pints of grain, and seven and a half pints of water.[104p]
    The large intestine weighs two jin and twelve liang, measures two zhang and one chi in length, four cun in width, and one cun in diameter. Located to the right of the navel, it curves back with sixteen bends, holding one dou of grains and seven and a half sheng of water.

    The bladder weighs nine liang and two zhu, measures nine cun in length and width, and can hold nine sheng and seven he of urine. The mouth is two and a half cun wide, with a distance of nine fen from the lips to the teeth, and three and a half cun deep from the teeth to the epiglottis, capable of holding five he.

    The tongue weighs ten liang, is seven cun long, and two and a half cun wide. The pharyngeal entrance weighs twelve liang, is two and a half cun wide, and extends one chi and six cun to the stomach.

    The throat weighs twelve liang, is two cun wide, and twelve cun long, divided into nine segments. The anus weighs twelve liang, measures eight cun in width, is two and a half cun in diameter, and is two zhang and eight cun long, holding nine sheng and three he of grains, and one eighth of a he.

    [Hua Shou comments: The meaning of this section appears in chapters thirty-one and thirty-two of the "Lingshu". The Yue people compiled it into one piece, and added the weights and capacities of the five organs in the latter part. Although there may be some repetition between sections, it does not detract from its importance. The quantities mentioned for holding and capacity vary, but they do not affect the main principles, so I have retained it for those who understand.][105p]
    The forty-third difficulty states: If a person does not eat or drink for seven days and dies, what is the reason? Indeed. A person's stomach should contain two dou of grains and one dou and five sheng of water. Thus, an average person defecates twice a day, approximately two and a half sheng each time, totaling five sheng at midday. In seven days, that amounts to five times seven, which is three dou and five sheng, and thus the water and grains are entirely depleted. Therefore, if an average person does not eat or drink for seven days, when the water and grains and their fluids are all exhausted, death occurs.

    [Hua Shou states: This section is similar to the thirtieth chapter of "Ling Shu." When the stomach is full, the intestines are empty; when the intestines are full, the stomach is empty. This fluctuation leads to the proper flow of qi, stabilizing the five organs, harmonizing the blood vessels, and allowing the spirit to reside, for the spirit is the essence of the water and grains. Therefore, if an average person does not eat or drink for seven days, all the water, grains, and their fluids are completely depleted. Hence, it is said that when water departs, nourishment disperses, and when grains are consumed, protection is lost. When nourishment disperses and protection is lost, the spirit has nowhere to rely; this is what is meant.][106p]
    The Forty-Fourth Difficulty states: Where are the seven orifices? Indeed. The lips are the flying gate, the teeth are the door, the epiglottis is the swallowing gate, the stomach is the entrance, the lower opening of the stomach is the幽门 (Yōumén or the "dark gate"), the meeting of the large and small intestines is the阑门 (Lánmén or the "barrier gate"), and the lower extremity is the魄门 (Pòmén or the "spirit gate"). Therefore, they are called the seven orifices.

    [Huashou comments: "冲" (chōng) means crucial. "会厌" refers to the epiglottis. "会" means to combine. "厌" means to cover, referring to the action of closing the throat when swallowing, preventing food from mistakenly entering and obstructing breath in and out. "贲" (bēn) and "奔" (bēn) are the same, indicating the sound of things rushing. The lower opening of the stomach is located two inches below the navel. The conjunction of the large and small intestines is at one inch above the water point of the navel. The lower extremity refers to the anus. "魄门" also carries the meaning of something hidden and profound.][107p]
    The Forty-Fifth Difficulty states: When the classics mention the Eight Meetings, what does it mean? Indeed. The meeting of the hollow organs is at Tai Cang, the meeting of the viscera is at Ji Xie, the meeting of the tendons is at Yang Ling Quan, the meeting of the marrow is at Jue Gu, the meeting of the blood is at Ge Yu, the meeting of the bones is at Da Zhu, the meeting of the vessels is at Tai Yuan, and the meeting of qi is at the outer Three Jiao, a straight channel between the two breasts. For internal heat diseases, one should apply to the acupoints where these meetings of qi are located.

    [Hua Shou states: Tai Cang, also known as Zhong Wan, is four inches above the navel. The six hollow organs derive their qualities from the stomach, thus it is the meeting of the hollow organs. Ji Xie corresponds to the Zhang Men point, located at the lateral edge of the navel at the lower rib ends, serving as the source of the spleen. The five viscera derive their qualities from the spleen, hence it is the meeting of the viscera. The channel of the foot Shao Yang converges at the outer edge of the knee, known as Yang Ling Quan, located one inch below the knee in the lateral depression; it corresponds to the gallbladder and liver, with the liver being the convergence of tendons, hence it is the meeting of the tendons. Jue Gu, also known as Yang Fu, is found four inches above the outer ankle, in front of Fu Gu, with the end of Jue Gu marked like the anterior third. All marrow belongs to the bones, thus it is the meeting of the marrow. Ge Yu is located under the seventh vertebra in the back, one and a half inches to either side of the spine; it is where the qi of the foot Tai Yang emerges. The Tai Yang meridian is abundant in blood, and blood symbolizes water, hence it is the meeting of the blood.][108p]
    The Dazhu point is located at the back of the neck, beneath the first vertebra, one and a half inches away from the spine on both sides. The Taiyuan point is found in the indentation of the radial artery at the back of the palm, known as the "cun kou"; it signifies the great meeting of the pulses. The Qi converges at the Sanjiao, along a straight line between the two breasts, known as the Danzhong, which is the sea of Qi and located one inch and six tenths below the Yutang. For internal heat diseases, one must examine and select points according to their respective locations.

    Xie notes: Sanjiao should be referred to as the Upper Jiao. Chen of Siming states that the marrow converges with the bones; marrow belongs to the kidneys, which govern the bones. The foot Shaoyang is unrelated here. The brain is the sea of marrow, and there is a point at the occipital bone, thereby it should correspond to the occipital bone; the misunderstanding is regarding the convergence with the bones. Blood converges at the Geyu point; blood is governed by the heart and stored in the liver. The Ge point is located below the seventh vertebra on both sides; above, it corresponds to the heart, and below, it corresponds to the liver, thus it is the convergence of blood. The bones converge at the Dazhu point; bones are nourished by the marrow, which extends from the brain to the Dazhu, seeping into the spinal core, passing down through the tail, infiltrating the joints; therefore, all the essence of the bones gathers here, thus it is also interconnected.

    Ancient Yi of the Yuan family stated: a person can walk robustly because the marrow converges with the bones; they can bear heavy burdens with their shoulders because the bones converge at the Dazhu.[109p]
    The 46th difficulty states: Why do the elderly lie down and not sleep, while the young sleep but do not awaken? Indeed. The text says that the young have abundant blood and energy, their muscles are supple, and their qi pathways are clear, therefore they are alert during the day and do not awaken at night. The elderly, however, have diminished blood and energy, their muscles are not supple, and their pathways of nourishment and defense are sluggish, thus they cannot stay alert during the day and cannot sleep at night. Therefore, it is understood why the elderly cannot sleep.

    [Huashou comments: The awakening of the elderly and the sleeping of the young are related to the surplus or deficiency of nourishment, defense, blood, and energy, consistent with the 18 chapters of the "Ling Shu."][110p]
    Section 47 states: Why can only the human face endure the cold? Indeed. The head is where all the Yang channels converge. All the Yin meridians reach the neck and chest and then return, while only the Yang meridians ascend to the head and ears, allowing the face to withstand the cold.

    [Huashou comments: In the fourth chapter of the "Ling Shu," it is stated that the head and face relate to the body’s form, belonging to the bones, connected by tendons, sharing blood, and united in Qi. When the heavens are cold, the earth cracks, and ice forms. Consequently, if hands and feet feel lethargic from the extreme cold, why does the face not cover up? Qibo says: The twelve primary meridians and three hundred sixty-five collateral pathways all have blood and Qi ascending to the face, moving through the orifices. The refined Yang Qi ascends to the eyes to form sight; the auxiliary Qi moves to the ears for hearing; the ancestral Qi rises from the nose for smell; the turbid Qi emerges from the stomach, travels through the lips and mouth for taste; and all the Qi and fluids ascend and steam the face. Additionally, the skin is thick, and the flesh is firm; thus, extreme heat and severe cold cannot overcome it. I humbly analyze that the three Yang channels from the hand run up to the head, the three Yang channels from the foot run down to the foot, the three Yin channels from the abdomen run to the hand, and the three Yin channels from the foot enter the abdomen. This explains why all the Yin meridians reach the neck and chest and then return, while only the Yang meridians ascend to the head and ears.][111p]
    The Forty-Eight Difficulties states: A person has three voids and three realities, what does this mean? Indeed, there is the void and reality of the pulse, the void and reality of disease, and the void and reality of diagnosis. The void and reality of the pulse are as follows: a soft pulse is considered void, while a tight and solid pulse is considered real. The void and reality of disease are: something that appears outwardly is considered void, while something that is internal is considered real; what is expressed is void, while what is unexpressed is real; a slow manifestation is void, while a rapid one is real. The void and reality of diagnosis are: a soft feeling is void, while a solid feeling is real; itching is void, while pain is real; external pain with internal comfort indicates external reality and internal void, while internal pain with external comfort indicates internal reality and external void. Thus it is called void and reality.

    [Hua Shou says: A soft pulse is void, while a tight pulse is real; this is the void and reality of the pulse. What appears outwardly is void, indicating that the internal organs are damaged from within to outside, as Dong Yuan described as internal injury. What enters inwardly is real, indicating that the five evils harm from outside to within, as Dong Yuan described as external injury.][112p]
    Words represent the void; when the internal organs become ill, it does not arise from external pathogens, hence the mind is clear and speech is not hindered. Those who do not speak represent the real; when a person harbors internal pathogenic qi, they become confused and do not speak. Those who are slow represent the void; slowness indicates they are not urgent, and what emerges from within is gradual and delayed, not a condition developed overnight. Those who are urgent represent the real; this speaks to illnesses caused by external pathogens like wind, cold, heat, etc., with life and death at stake between five and six days. This describes the reality of the illness's void and real aspects.

    To diagnose is to assess and observe. By examining the outside, one comes to know it, not merely by pulse diagnosis. Softness indicates the void, firmness indicates the real; these two sentences are not found in the classic texts, although the Xie family believes them to be later additions. Yang’s interpretation states that when the skin and flesh are soft and moist, it signifies the void, while tightness and strength indicate the real; thus, the presence of either does no harm.

    When palpating the area of illness, if the painful spot is discerned, it indicates the real; thus, if it is not painful but itchy, it is not the real condition. Additionally, if there is external pain but internal ease, it signifies that the pathogen is strong externally; conversely, if there is internal pain but external ease, it suggests the pathogen is strong internally. Generally, when pathogenic qi is vigorous, it is the real; when vital essence is depleted, it is the void. This explains the diagnosis of the void and the real.[113p]
    In the section on the forty-nine difficulties, it is stated: When there is an affliction of the regular channels or an injury from the five evils, how can one distinguish between them? Indeed, anxiety and worry injure the heart; exposure to cold and drinking cold liquids injure the lungs; anger and excessive emotions that rise without descending injure the liver; overindulgence in food and fatigue injure the spleen; prolonged sitting on damp ground or overexertion in water injure the kidneys. These are afflictions of the regular channels.

    Huashou says: The heart governs thought and is the sovereign’s organ, thus anxiety and worry injure the heart. The lungs govern the skin and hair and are considered delicate organs, hence exposure to cold and drinking cold liquids injure the lungs. The liver governs anger, and anger injures the liver. The spleen governs eating, drinking, and the limbs, so overindulgence in food and fatigue injure the spleen. The kidneys govern the bones and are associated with water; therefore, excessive effort and sitting in damp conditions injure the kidneys. All of this arises from excess in worry, anger, eating, and physical activity.[114p]
    Worry and thought, anger, eating and drinking, actions—these are things that no one can be without. When they are expressed in moderation, they cause no harm; if excessive, they will certainly injure a person. Therefore, those who are good at preserving life avoid extremes and seek a middle path. The ignorant, however, become fixated and wish to reject everything, which is not sensible at all! This is similar to the fourth chapter of the "Lingshu," but differs in that it mentions a condition where one becomes hurt in the spleen due to sweating from being drunk and exposed to the wind, which is not the same.

    Xie states: Eating and drinking and labor and fatigue are indeed two different matters. When eating and drinking are well-timed, one feels hunger and satiety. Labor and fatigue arise from overexertion and lead to exhaustion. The fundamental principle here indicates that illness comes from within the body, not from external pathogens, which is what is meant by "internal injury." Some might say that sitting in dampness or entering water is also something acquired from outside, so why is this considered an internal illness? The reply is that this is not one of the six external evils of nature.[115p]
    What are the five evils? They are: wind, summer heat, dietary labor, cold, and dampness.

    [Hua Shou said: Wind corresponds to wood and tends to injure the liver. Heat corresponds to fire and tends to injure the heart. Earth is related to agriculture, and the spleen governs the limbs, therefore dietary labor tends to injure the spleen. Cold corresponds to metal and tends to injure the lungs. As stated in the "Zuo Zhuan": metal is cold. Dampness corresponds to water and tends to injure the kidneys, along with mist, rain, and vapor. These five evils are external injuries, referred to as external harms.]

    [Xie said: Spleen and stomach pathologies arise from labor and exhaustion; injuries from the five evils arise from diet.]

    Suppose there is a heart disease, how can one ascertain if it is due to wind? In that case, the color should be red. Why is this said? The liver governs color: entering the lungs, it becomes white; entering the spleen, yellow; entering the heart, red; entering the kidneys, black. The liver is the source of heart evil, hence it is known to be red. The symptoms include body heat, fullness and pain in the flanks, with a pulse that is floating, large, and tense.

    [Hua Shou said: This is an example concerning the heart, hypothetically derived from it. The liver governs color, the liver is the source of heart evil, hence the redness and body heat. A floating, large pulse indicates the heart, while flank pain and a tense pulse indicate the liver.][116p]
    How do we know that heat injury is related to summer? Yes, it is accompanied by a foul odor. How can we explain this? The heart is associated with odors; when injured by heat, it produces a burnt smell, a fragrant smell when affecting the spleen, a rancid smell when affecting the liver, a rotten smell when affecting the kidneys, and a fishy smell when affecting the lungs. Therefore, we understand that heart conditions from summer heat are accompanied by foul odors. The patient experiences body heat, agitation, and pain in the heart, with a pulse that is floating, large, and scattered.

    [Huá Shòu commented: The heart is associated with odors; when the heart is damaged by summer heat, it faces illness, hence the aversion to foul smells, and the symptoms and pulse diagnosis all pertain to the heart.]

    How do we know that issues from diet and fatigue arise? Yes, it is characterized by a preference for bitter tastes, with deficiency leading to loss of appetite and abundance leading to increased appetite. How can we explain this? The spleen governs tastes; when it affects the liver, it produces a sour taste; when it affects the heart, a bitter taste; when it affects the lungs, a spicy taste; when it affects the kidneys, a salty taste; and when it affects itself, a sweet taste. Thus, we know that spleen dysfunction affecting the heart leads to a preference for bitter tastes. The patient experiences body heat, a heavy sensation, a desire to lie down, and limbs that are unresponsive, with a pulse that is floating, large, and slow.

    [Huá Shòu commented: The spleen governs tastes, and the spleen is related to heart dysfunction, hence the preference for bitter tastes. The body heat and large, floating pulse indicate heart issues. The heavy sensation and desire to lie down, combined with unresponsive limbs and a slow pulse, suggest spleen involvement. The lines on loss of appetite and increased appetite do not match the context and may be erroneous.][117p]
    How can we know if the illness is due to Cold Damage? Indeed, it comes with delirious speech. How do we say this? The lungs govern sound; when the evil enters the heart, it causes confusion in speech; when it enters the liver, it leads to weeping; when it enters the heart, it results in speech; when it enters the spleen, it manifests as song; when it enters the kidneys, it brings out moans; and when it enters oneself, it leads to crying. Thus, it is understood that the lung's evil entering the heart is the cause of the delirious speech. The symptoms include body heat, chills, and possibly severe coughing, with a pulse that is floating, large, and coarse.

    What indicates that the illness is due to Internal Dampness? Indeed, there is a tendency to sweat that cannot be stopped. How do we discern this? The kidneys govern dampness; when it enters the liver, it leads to tears; when it enters the heart, it leads to sweating; when it enters the spleen, it leads to saliva; when it enters the lungs, it causes nasal discharge; and when it enters oneself, it results in spittle. Hence, it is understood that the kidney's evil entering the heart causes sweating that cannot be stopped. The symptoms are body heat accompanied by pain in the lower abdomen, cold extremities, and a pulse that is submerged, moist, and large. This describes the principles of the Five Evils.

    In general, the qi of the yin, yang, organs, and meridians should be balanced. An excess or deficiency leads to a loss of the proper state, which then becomes an evil. This text discusses the imbalances in the yin-yang organs and meridians. When there is an excess, internal evils arise; when there is a deficiency, external evils can invade.[118p]
    In the Fifty Difficulties, it is said: There are various types of illness—virtual pathogens, real pathogens, marauding pathogens, subtle pathogens, and correct pathogens. How can one distinguish between them? The later ones are called virtual pathogens, the earlier ones are called real pathogens, those that are overwhelming are called marauding pathogens, those that are dominated are called subtle pathogens, and those that arise from the patient themselves are called correct pathogens.

    Why do we say this? For instance, in the case of heart diseases: a stroke that comes afterward is a virtual pathogen, heat stroke that occurs as the main illness is a correct pathogen, illness due to dietary strain or fatigue that comes from the front is a real pathogen, a cold injury that arises from being overcome is a subtle pathogen, and dampness that comes from what one cannot withstand is a marauding pathogen.

    Using the heart as an example clarifies the above meaning. A stroke as a virtual pathogen comes afterwards, with fire in front and wood behind. A heat stroke as a correct pathogen is derived from the illness itself (fire). Dietary strain or fatigue is a real pathogen, coming from the front (earth in front and fire behind). A cold injury is a subtle pathogen, stemming from what one is vanquished by (fire overcomes metal). Dampness is a marauding pathogen, arising from what one cannot withstand (water restraining fire). The relationship with the previous section should be examined carefully for mutual understanding.[119p]
    The fifty-first difficulty states: There are patients who desire warmth, some who desire coolness, some who wish to see others, and some who prefer not to be seen, and each case is different; it depends on which organ system is affected. Therefore, those who desire coolness and wish to see others have a condition in the fu (bowel) organs; those who desire warmth and do not wish to see others have a condition in the zang (visceral) organs. Why is this so? The fu represents yang, and yang conditions wish for coolness while also desiring social interaction. The zang represents yin, and yin conditions desire warmth, wishing to stay secluded and dislike hearing voices, thus indicating the distinction between illnesses of the zang and fu organs.

    [The Ji family states: The fu represents yang. In the case of yang illness, there is an excess of heat and a deficiency of coolness, hence the desire for food, clothing, and living conditions to be cool. Yang is active and responds to the external, leading to the desire for social contact. The zang represents yin. In the case of yin illness, there is an excess of coolness and a deficiency of heat, thus the need for food, clothing, and living conditions to be warm. Yin is characterized by stillness and responds to the internal, resulting in the desire to stay secluded and a dislike of hearing voices.][120p]
    In the Fifty-Second Difficulty it is stated: Are the organs and bowels fundamentally the same? No, they are not the same. How are they not the same? The diseases of the organs are fixed and do not move; their ailments do not leave their place. The diseases of the bowels, however, resemble a flow that moves up and down, with no fixed position, thus indicating that the organs and bowels are fundamentally different.

    [The Ding clan states: Diseases of the organs are yin, and yin represents stillness, hence they are fixed and do not move. Diseases of the bowels are yang, and yang represents motion, thus they flow up and down, with no fixed position. This explanation interrelates with the text of the Fifty-Fifth Difficulty.]

    In the Fifty-Third Difficulty it is stated: The classics say that in the seven transmissions, one dies, and in the intervening organs, one lives; what does this mean? The seven transmissions are from one to another as they overcome their predecessor, while the intervening organs are transmitted to their offspring. Why is this said? For example, if the heart disease transmits to the lungs, the lungs transmit to the liver, the liver transmits to the spleen, the spleen transmits to the kidneys, and the kidneys transmit back to the heart, if no organ suffers further damage, it is stated that the seven transmissions result in death.

    [The Ji clan states: The heart fire transmits to the lung metal, the lung metal transmits to the liver wood, the liver wood transmits to the spleen earth, the spleen earth transmits to the kidney water, and the kidney water transmits back to the heart fire. The heart fire receiving the transmission from water counts as one; the lung metal receiving the transmission from fire counts as two. Starting from the heart and sequentially transmitting to the lung is seven transmissions, thus the death from the seven transmissions means that no organ receives further damage.][121p]
    If the heart's illness transmits to the spleen, the spleen transmits to the lungs, the lungs transmit to the kidneys, the kidneys transmit to the liver, and the liver transmits back to the heart, this is the mutual transmission between child and mother, continuing in a cycle without end; therefore, it is said to be life.

    [Hua Shou says: Lü Shi states that the transmission among organs occurs through the organ that it overcomes. The heart overcomes the lungs, thus the spleen transmits to the lungs; the spleen overcomes the kidneys, thus the lungs transmit to the kidneys; the lungs overcome the liver, thus the kidneys transmit to the liver; the kidneys overcome the heart, thus the liver transmits to the heart; and the liver overcomes the spleen, thus the heart transmits to the spleen. This is what is meant by the transmission of what gives rise to life. I humbly note that in the "Su Wen" on the theory of transmission of primary and secondary ailments, it states: Observe the intervals closely and adjust accordingly. The intervals signify mutual functioning, whereas "excess" indicates singular action. The mutual functioning signifies a joint transmission, transmitting what it overlaps, which is similar to Lü Shi's explanation. Singular action signifies a distinctive transmission towards what is overcome, as described in Ji Shi's argument. The principle of the Yue people fundamentally arises from this, detailed in this chapter and in the 42nd chapter of "Ling Shu." However, the principle in these two texts indicates that the transmission occurs among the five organs, along with the stomach and bladder, totaling seven. They elaborate their examples, and each text is named for the transmission of ailments. Now, the Yue people refer to the seven transmissions among the organs, elucidating the principles from these two texts, using the heart as an example to demonstrate the mutual transmission of ailments. If transmission occurs towards what is overcome, and a single organ suffers twice, it results in death; if it is an interval of overcoming, as a mutual transmission between child and mother, it leads to life. This is particularly clear and straightforward.][122p]
    The Fifty-Fourth Problem states: Diseases of the organs are difficult to treat, while diseases of the bowels are easy to treat. What does this mean? Indeed, the difficulty in treating organ diseases arises because they transmit what overcomes them; conversely, bowel diseases are easy to treat because they transmit what they produce. Treatment approaches for both organs and bowels share similarities in the context of the seven transmissions.

    Hua Shou remarks: Chen from Siming states that the five organs are guarded internally by the seven spirits, hence the subtle invasions are not easily transmitted. When substantial qi enters, the spirits lose their guard, leading to deeper illness, making treatment challenging, possibly even resulting in death. The six bowels are involved in the processes of transfer and transformation; their qi remains constantly open. Moreover, the gallbladder, being a clear and pure space, makes it difficult for pathogens to linger deep, thus bowel diseases are easier to treat.

    From the perspective of the Yue people, it can be interpreted that the difficulty in treating organ diseases comes from their ability to transmit what overcomes them, while bowel diseases are easier to treat since they transmit what they generate. However, this is merely one aspect of their nature. If organ diseases transmit what they generate, they would also be easy to treat, and if bowel diseases transmit what overcomes them, they would become difficult to treat. Hence, Pang Anchang often said that among the medical texts of this world, only the words of Bian Que hold depth, which is what the "Nanjing" refers to.

    The Yue people embed skills within their writings; if there are unclear parts, they encourage future generations to seek deeper understanding, right? Now, with this text, it can be said that Pang has truly grasped the essence of the Yue people.[123p]
    The fifty-fifth difficulty states: Diseases can be classified as accumulation or congestion; how can we distinguish between them? Indeed, accumulation pertains to yin qi, while congestion pertains to yang qi. Therefore, accumulation is deep and latent, while congestion is superficial and active. The place where qi accumulates is called accumulation, and the place where qi gathers is called congestion. Thus, accumulation arises from the five viscera, while congestion is produced by the six bowels. Accumulation, being yin qi, has a fixed place of origin; its pain does not stray from its region, with a clear beginning and end, both upward and downward, as well as boundaries to the left and right. Congestion, being yang qi, lacks a fundamental origin; it has no fixed point to pause, and its pain is variable in location, which is why it is termed congestion. Hence, this is how we differentiate between accumulation and congestion.

    [Shu Shou remarked: Accumulation arises from the five viscera, which are associated with yin and represent stillness; therefore, its ailments are deep-seated and do not leave their location. Congestion comes from the six bowels, which are associated with yang and represent movement; hence, its ailments are superficial and do not remain in one place.]

    [Yang commented: Accumulation means storage, indicating that when the flow of blood and qi is obstructed, it leads to disease.]

    [Zhou Zhongli stated: The deep and latent nature of accumulation is initially imperceptible, gradually growing and building up over time. Congestion, on the other hand, is where the disease manifests, occurring coincidentally with blood and qi, thus it lacks a constant location, in agreement with the concepts of the fifty-second difficulty.][124p]
    The fifty-sixth difficulty states: Are there specific names for the accumulations in the five organs? On what days and months are they obtained? Indeed. The accumulation of the liver is called "fat qi," located beneath the left rib, resembling an overturned cup, with a head and foot. If it endures for a long time, it can cause coughing and reverse flow, leading to malaria that persists for years. It is obtained on the Wujia days of late summer. How can this be explained? Lung disease transmits to the liver, which should transmit to the spleen. In late summer, the ruler’s body does not accept evils; hence, the liver wants to return to the lung, but the lung refuses to accept it, resulting in a blocked accumulation, thus one knows that fat qi is obtained on the Wujia days of late summer.

    [Huashou says: "Fat" refers to fullness. The presence of a head and foot indicates a significant beginning and end. Cough and reverse flow are the distinctions of the foot jueyin, passing through the diaphragm to the lung. Liver disease causes coughing in the chest. Malaria occurs every two days; according to the Inner Canon, all five organs can have malaria, and here it is associated with wind malaria in the liver. Furthermore, malaria represents cold and heat diseases, mostly belonging to the lesser yang; the liver corresponds in both surface and interior, hence it is said to be beneath the left rib, the region of the liver.]

    The accumulation of the heart is called "fuliang," arising above the navel, as large as an arm, extending up to below the heart. If it endures for a long time, it causes vexation of the heart. It is obtained on the Gengxin days of autumn. How can this be explained? Kidney disease transmits to the heart, which should transmit to the lung. The lung, in autumn, aligns with the ruler's body, and the ruler does not accept evils; thus, the heart wishes to return to the kidney, but the kidney refuses, resulting in a blocked accumulation, hence one knows that fuliang is obtained on the Gengxin days of autumn.

    [Huashou says: Fuliang is still and unmoving, like a beam of wood.][125p]
    The accumulation of the spleen is called "phlegm-qi," located in the stomach area, as large as a plate. If it does not heal for a long time, it causes the limbs to become retracted, leads to jaundice, and impedes the nourishment to the skin. It is brought about by the winter days of Ren and Gui. Why is this said? Diseases of the liver pass to the spleen, while the spleen should pass to the kidneys. The kidneys correspond with the winter, and a sovereign does not accept evil influences; the spleen wishes to return to the liver, but the liver refuses to accept it, hence it remains as an accumulation. Thus, phlegm-qi is known to arise from the winter days of Ren and Gui.

    [Huashou commented: Phlegm-qi is a blockage that does not flow. Jaundice refers to yellowing. Damp heat causes jaundice.]

    The accumulation of the lungs is called "xi-bin," located under the right rib, as large as a cup. If it does not subside for a long time, it causes cold and heat sensations, coughing, and potential lung congestion. It arises on the spring days of Jia and Yi. Why is this said? Diseases of the heart pass to the lungs, while the lungs should pass to the liver. The liver corresponds with the spring, and a sovereign does not accept evil influences; the lungs wish to return to the heart, but the heart refuses to accept it, hence it remains as an accumulation. Thus, xi-bin is known to arise from the spring days of Jia and Yi.

    [Huashou commented: Xi-bin can manifest as either "xi" or "bin." The lung area under the right rib is associated with the skin and hair, hence the sensations of cold and heat. While it is said that organ diseases do not transfer but remain, the lung accumulation may manifest variably; this is because the lungs govern qi. Hence, the ailments may act periodically. The kidneys also govern qi, so the same applies to bin as well.][126p]
    The accumulation in the kidneys is called "ben tun," which emerges from the lower abdomen and rises to beneath the heart, resembling a pig. It can shift upwards or downwards at any time. If it persists for a long time, it causes wheezing, reverse breathing, bone atrophy, and shortness of breath. It is gained on the days of Bing and Ding in the summer. Why is it said this way? The disease of the spleen transmits to the kidneys, and the kidneys are supposed to transmit to the heart; when the heart governs summer, the sovereign does not accept evil influences, so the kidneys want to return to the spleen, but the spleen will not accept it, resulting in an accumulation. Thus, it is known that "ben tun" is gained in the summer on the days of Bing and Ding. This is the essential method for the five accumulations.

    Hua Shou said: "Ben tun" is not fixed like the protrusions of a pig; the nature of the pig is restless, hence its name. The cause of wheezing and reverse breathing is the channel of the foot shaoyin, which originates from the lungs and connects to the heart, entering the chest. It is difficult to speak only of the diseases of the viscera without mentioning the diseases of the bowels; Ji's theory states this is because it does not manifest in a constant place. Yang's theory suggests that the six bowels also transmit one another, just as the five viscera do.

    If one asks about the principles of things in the world, there is sensation and transmission; sensation is feeling, and transmission is qi. Where there is feeling, there is sensation; where there is qi, there is transmission. Now, the accumulation in the five viscera arises specifically because the qi overwhelms what cannot be transmitted.[127p]
    As for a ruler not being influenced by corruption, that is indeed true. However, if one is unable to prevail, they may desire to return to that which they have conquered. If the conquered do not accept this and instead hold on, this would indicate an emotional response. Moreover, the five organs within the human body each function as a distinct entity, akin to how the ears serve hearing and the eyes serve sight, each having their own roles but lacking thought; unlike humans, who engage with their surroundings with the heart as the master, guided by the dynamics of energy. Therefore, do the five organs truly possess emotions and responses? It is said that the thoughts of the people of Yue are based on the principles of the five elements, interpreted and articulated; initially, there is no need to argue about their emotions and responses, nor whether they reciprocate, as this is inherently unnecessary. For readers, simply consider the dynamic of conquering and not conquering, alongside the ruler’s resistance to corruption, leading to the accumulation of observations. This way, one can contemplate without letting language impair intent and think beyond the norm. Should anyone question the transmission of emotions and responses through energy, referencing the words of the earlier sages; it is said that the interaction of form influences the response of energy, so energy is indeed capable of responding. How does this relate to your words? It is stated that the teachings of earlier sages, although discussing energy’s responses, stem from the interaction of form. The form refers to the human body, which serves as the primary agent of perception.[128p]
    The fifty-seventh difficulty states: How many kinds of "leakage" are there? Are they all named? Yes. There are five types of leakage, each with a different name: gastric leakage, spleen leakage, large intestine leakage, small intestine leakage, and a condition called "heavy posterior" leakage.

    Gastric leakage occurs when food does not digest, resulting in a yellow color.

    Spleen leakage presents as abdominal distention, fullness, and when food is consumed, it causes vomiting or regurgitation.

    Large intestine leakage is characterized by difficulties after eating, with stool appearing white and accompanied by painful intestinal sounds.

    Small intestine leakage manifests as urination and bowel movements with pus and blood, accompanied by pain in the lower abdomen.[129p]
    The major type of dysentery involves urgent sensations in the abdomen, a heavy feeling in the posterior, frequent attempts to defecate without success, and pain in the genitals. This is the essential method related to the five types of dysentery.

    [Hua Shou said: "Dysentery refers to a blockage, suggesting that it arises from a solidified condition. The term 'urgent sensation' indicates pressure within the abdomen, and 'heavy feeling in the posterior' refers to a sense of weight at the anus. It is due to this urgency and heaviness that one frequently attempts to defecate but cannot. Pain in the genitals indicates also a lack of ease in urination."]

    [Xie said: "The dysentery of the small and large intestines is what is now referred to as dysentery. The 'Inner Canon' states that if the intestines are troubled, leading to dysentery with red or white discharge, moxibustion should be applied to the small intestine points, located below the sixteenth vertebra, one and a half inches on either side, as has been confirmed through many trials."]

    [Chen from Siming said: "Stomach dysentery is also known as 'food-related diarrhea.' Spleen dysentery is termed 'fluid-related diarrhea.' Large intestine dysentery is referred to as 'unblocked diarrhea.' Small intestine dysentery implies that when there is diarrhea, urination occurs first, leading to bloody urine, which is known as 'blood dysentery.' Major dysentery relates to intestinal disturbance."]

    The Fifty-Eighth Difficulty states: How many types are there of cold damage? Are there changes in the pulses? Yes. Cold damage has five types: wind attack, cold damage, damp-heat, heat sickness, and warm disease, each with distinct ailments.

    [Hua Shou said: "The term 'changes' should be 'distinctions,' referring to differentiating the pulses."]

    [Ji said: "Sweating with aversion to wind is called a 'wind attack.' Lacking sweat with aversion to cold is called 'cold damage.' Severe pain throughout the body, making it impossible to turn over, is termed 'damp-heat.' Injury from cold in winter that manifests in summer is termed 'heat sickness.' Conditions present at inappropriate times, throughout the year, having similar ailments, are termed 'warm disease.'"][130p]
    The pulse of a stroke is yang, floating and slippery, while yin is moist and weak. The pulse of damp-warmth is yang, floating and weak, while yin is small and rapid. The pulse of cold damage shows both yin and yang robust, tight and rough. The pulse of heat disease presents both yin and yang as floating; it is slippery when floating and scattered and rough when sinking. The pulse of warm disease travels through various channels, without knowing which channel it affects; treatment is based on the location of the pulse.

    [Shuo Shou said: The previous discussion was about identifying cold damage; this section discusses the distinction of the pulse, with yin and yang referring to dimensions.]

    [Yang said: Warm disease is caused by epidemic qi; it is not simply the cold of winter transforming into warm disease in spring. It spreads through various channels, thus cannot be predicted. One must examine the patient to identify the affected channel and then treat accordingly.]

    [Xie said: The "Zhongjing Treatise on Cold Damage" states that during severe winter, all creatures hibernate; a gentleman who is careful remains unharmed by the cold, while those who are careless are termed as suffering from cold damage. Any harm from seasonal qi can lead to illness, but cold damage is labeled as a toxin due to its lethal nature. Those who immediately show illness are termed as suffering from cold damage, while those who do not show illness have cold toxins hidden in their skin, which may transform into warm disease in spring or summer disease in summer. Summer disease is characterized by intense heat, exceeding that of warm disease.][131p]
    It is also said that the yang pulse is floating and slippery, while the yin pulse is moist and weak; when encountering wind, it transforms into wind-heat. According to Zhang Zhongjing's examples, wind-heat aligns with the pulses described in the "Nan Jing," without mentioning damp-heat. Furthermore, it is said in the "Nan Jing" that warm diseases refer to the warm malaria, wind-heat, warm toxin, and warm epidemic mentioned in Zhang Zhongjing's "Shang Han Lun." The people of Yue discuss its general concept but do not delve into details, while Zhang Zhongjing reveals its secrets and categorizes the pulses, which can be considered thorough.

    Pang Anchang in the "General Treatise on Cold Damage" states that the "Nan Jing" records five types of cold damage, discussing the pulses of warm diseases found across various channels, but it is unclear which channel's movement is being referred to, as one should take it according to the location of the channels. According to the "Nan Jing," warm diseases also arise from four types of cold damage that manifest differently.

    As Wang Shuhe states, when the yang pulse is floating and slippery, and the yin pulse is moist and weak, if it further encounters wind, it transforms into wind-heat. When the yang pulse is surging and rapid, and the yin pulse is solid and large, if it further encounters damp heat, it transforms into warm toxin; warm toxin is the most severe of diseases. When the yang pulse is moist and weak, and the yin pulse is tense and tight, if it further encounters dampness, it transforms into damp-heat. When both yin and yang pulses are robust but heavily affected by cold, it transforms into warm malaria. These cases exhibit the same diseases under different names and different pulses across various channels, which illustrates the idea of taking it according to the location of the channels. While Pang's view may not align with the "Nan Jing," it still carries a similar meaning. However, the "Shang Han Lun" discusses warm epidemics without mentioning damp-heat, while Shuhe discusses damp-heat without mentioning warm epidemics; this is indeed a difference.[132p]
    In the case of cold damage, there are those who sweat and recover but die upon purging, and others who sweat and die but recover upon purging. What is the reason for this? Indeed. When Yang is deficient and Yin is excess, sweating leads to recovery; purging causes death. Conversely, when Yang is excess and Yin is deficient, sweating leads to death; purging results in recovery.

    [Hua Shou said: When the disease is due to deficiency, it is considered weak; when the disease does not occur, it is seen as excess. It is precisely because of the deficiency that the evil enters; it is only due to excess that the evil cannot infiltrate. This refers to the idea in the "External Treatise" regarding exterior illnesses being harmonized with interior conditions, and interior illnesses being harmonized with exterior conditions, specifically concerning the changes in cold damage. When the exterior illness is harmonized with the interior, sweating can be appropriate, but when purging is done instead, the exterior evil remains, and the interior qi is compromised; when the interior illness is harmonized with the exterior, purging can be appropriate, but when sweating is attempted instead, the interior evil does not subside, and the exterior qi is compromised, resulting in death. Therefore, it is said that sweating can deplete Yang, while purging can harm Yin. The terms Yin and Yang are used here in relation to the exterior and interior. The classics say: "Punishment without exceeding is called great confusion." Is this what it refers to?][133p]
    How should one observe the illnesses of cold and heat? Indeed. For skin cold and heat, the skin should not be near the bed, hair scorched, and the nose dry without sweating. For muscle cold and heat, the skin is painful, lips and tongue dry without sweating. For bone cold and heat, the patient finds no comfort, sweat streams incessantly, and teeth are painful and dry.

    [Hua Shou says: "In the twenty-first chapter of 'Ling Shu', it states that for skin cold and heat, one must not be near the bed, with hair scorched, nose dry and unable to sweat. One should take the three yang channels to nourish the hand Tai Yin. For muscle cold and heat, if the muscles ache, hair scorched and lips dry without sweating, one should take the three yang from below to expel the blood, nourishing the Tai Yin to promote sweating. For bone cold and heat, the patient finds no comfort,"]

    [I mean that the hundred pulses throughout the body are not well. If sweating is incessant and the teeth are not yet dry, take from the lesser yin channel at the thigh; if the teeth are already dry, it will not be treatable. I humbly note that this is likely an illness of internal injury, associated with similar symptoms. Does Dong Yuan's 'Distinction of Inner and Outer Injuries' indicate its signs here?][134p]
    The Sixty-Ninth Difficulty discusses how to differentiate between mania and epilepsy. When mania first manifests, there is little sleep accompanied by a lack of hunger. It is characterized by a sense of superiority, discernment of wisdom, arrogance, excessive laughter, enjoyment of singing and music, and incessant wandering. When epilepsy first manifests, there is a lack of joy, rigidity, and a fixed stare, with the pulse showing strength in both yin and yang.

    Huashou explains that mania arises from yang; thus, its symptoms are characterized by excess and activity. Epilepsy arises from yin, so its symptoms are characterized by deficiency and stillness. The pulse being strong in both yin and yang indicates that mania drives from yang, leading to a strong yang pulse. Conversely, if epilepsy arises from yin, it results in a strong yin pulse. In the twenty difficulties, the concepts of heavy yang correspond to mania, heavy yin to epilepsy, loss of yang to seeing spirits, and loss of yin to blindness; these should be associated with the discussions above. The term "heavy" should be pronounced like "twice heavy."

    Chen from Siming states that when qi is concentrated in yang, it results in heavy yang; when blood is concentrated in yin, it results in heavy yin. Loss of yang leads to seeing spirits, which indicates qi is not fixed; loss of yin leads to blindness, showing that blood does not nourish. The discussion of mania and epilepsy is detailed in the twenty-first chapter of the Nei Jing, but the Yue people specifically summarize it, likely inviting later generations to seek their own understanding.[135p]
    The sixty difficulties state: As for the ailments of the head and heart, there are two types of pain: one is termed "Jue pain" and the other "true pain." What do these mean? Jue head pain arises when the three Yang meridians of the hands receive cold and wind that lingers and does not dissipate.

    As for true head pain, it is characterized by severe pain, with pain penetrating deeply into the brain, and the extremities may turn blue down to the joints; it is hopeless if left untreated. This is because the essence and true energy are concentrated in the brain’s marrow, which should not be afflicted by evil; if afflicted, it leads to death.

    When the qi of the five organs interconnects improperly, it is called "Jue heart pain."[136p]
    Hua Shou said: "The 'Lingshu' records five types of heart pain: stomach heart pain, kidney heart pain, spleen heart pain, liver heart pain, and lung heart pain, all of which are caused by the evil qi of the five organs."

    If the pain is severe but localized in the heart, and the hands and feet appear bluish, it is called true heart pain. True heart pain can cause death by morning if it occurs in the evening, or by evening if it starts in the morning. Hua Shou further explained: "The 'Lingshu' states that true heart pain manifests with extreme pain in the heart and bluish coloration of the hands and feet down to the joints. The seventy-first chapter mentions that the lesser yin pertains to the heart vessels, and the heart is the supreme organ in the body. The heart serves as the ruler where the spirit resides; if the organ is robust, evil cannot intrude. If it does intrude, it harms the heart; when the heart is harmed, the spirit departs, and when the spirit departs, death ensues. 'True heart pain' should have an omitted character before the word 'true', which indicates a textual omission. The 'bluish' of the hands and feet should be understood as 'cold'."

    The sixty-first difficult question states: "To know through observation is called spirit, to know through hearing is called sage, to know through inquiry is called skilled, and to know through pulse diagnosis is called clever; what does this mean? Indeed, knowing through observation means seeing the five colors to diagnose the illness." Hua Shou added: "In the 'Suwen', the section on the generation of the five organs states that seeing colors: blue like lush grass indicates death, yellow like bitter orange indicates death, black like charcoal indicates death, red like fresh blood indicates death, and white like dry bones indicates death; these are the manifestations of death in the five colors. Blue like emerald indicates life, red like a rooster's comb indicates life, yellow like crab belly indicates life, white like pig fat indicates life, and black like crow feathers indicates life; these are the manifestations of life in the five colors."[137p]
    Born in the heart, the desire appears as red wrapped in white; born in the lungs, the desire appears as crimson wrapped in white; born in the liver, the desire appears as deep blue wrapped in white; born in the spleen, the desire appears as gourd fruit wrapped in white; born in the kidneys, the desire appears as purple wrapped in white. These are the colors arising from the five organs as external manifestations.

    In the "Spiritual Pivot," Chapter 49, it states: black and blue indicate pain, yellow and red indicate heat, and white indicates cold. It also says if red appears on both cheekbones, the size of a thumb, though the sickness is minor, recovery will likely lead to sudden death; if black appears in the yard, the size of a thumb, it will lead to sudden death without illness. Furthermore, Chapter 74 states: when diagnosing blood vessels, much red and much heat indicate issues, much blue and much pain suggest problems, much black indicates chronic numbness, and the appearance of black, red, and blue together indicates cold, heat, and body ache. A slightly yellow complexion, yellow dental plaque, and yellowing nails indicate jaundice.

    Similarly, in examining childbirth, if the face is red and the tongue is toxic, the mother lives but the child dies; if the face is blue and the tongue is blue with froth, the mother dies but the child lives; if both lips and mouth are blue, both mother and child die, and so forth.

    Yuan commented: the colors of the five organs seen on the face each correspond to parts that reflect their interactions of generation and overcoming, allowing one to observe and understand the illness.[138p]
    One who hears and understands can discern the ailments by recognizing the five sounds.

    [Hua Shou stated: The Chen family of Siming says that the five viscera have sounds, and these sounds possess different tones. The liver emits a call that corresponds to the "jiao" tone; when it is tuned and aligned, there is no illness; if it is chaotic, the disease lies in the liver. The heart produces a laughter that corresponds to the "zheng" tone; when it is harmonious and prolonged, there is no illness; if it is disordered, the disease lies in the heart. The spleen sings, corresponding to the "gong" tone; when it is large and harmonious, there is no illness; if it is disrupted, the disease lies in the spleen. The lungs emit a cry that corresponds to the "shang" tone; when it is light and vigorous, there is no illness; if it is chaotic, the disease lies in the lungs. The kidneys moan, corresponding to the "yu" tone; when it is deep and profound, there is no illness; if it is disordered, the disease lies in the kidneys.]

    [Yuan's commentary: By hearing the sounds of the five viscera and their corresponding tones, one can distinguish their illnesses based on the clarity or muddiness of these sounds, whether they dominate or are subdued, or exhibit harsh qualities.]

    [This section aligns with discussions in the "Suwen" regarding the correspondence of yin and yang, the theories of "Jinkui Zhenyan," and inquiries about the sounds of the five viscera. Therefore, hearing their sounds is sufficient for discerning ailments.][139p]
    To understand one's illness, one should inquire about their cravings for the five flavors, as this reveals the origins and locations of their ailment.

    Hua Shou said: "In the sixty-third chapter of the 'Ling Shu,' it states that each of the five flavors affects different bodily functions and can lead to various health issues. Sour affects the tendons; excessive consumption can result in urinary problems. Salty affects the blood; too much can lead to thirst. Spicy affects the vital energy; overconsumption may disturb the heart. Since spicy enhances the flow of energy, it also promotes sweating. Bitter affects the bones; consuming too much can lead to nausea. Sweet affects the flesh; overindulgence may cause a heavy feeling in the heart. From this, one can understand that asking about cravings for the five flavors helps identify the source of their ailments."

    Yuan's remark: "If one shows a strong preference or excessive consumption of a particular flavor among the five, it indicates an imbalance in the organ energies, revealing a tendency towards deficiency or excess."[140p]
    To know through palpation, one examines the radial pulse, observing its vacuity and solidity to discern the illness and identify which organ is affected.

    【Hua Shou says: Examining the radial pulse relates to the First Difficulty. Observing vacuity and solidity allows one to encounter the Six Difficulties and the Forty-Eight Difficulties. Wang's Treatise on Pulse states: There are three divisions of pulse, namely, the cun (inch), chi (palm), and guan (bar). The flow of nourishing and guarding energy remains balanced. The kidney pulse is deep, the heart is surging, the lung is superficial, and the liver is taut. This adheres to the regular classics, without losing precision. Movements in rising and descending, the pulse revolving around itself. Water beneath a hundred beats, the pulse encircling the whole body. When returning to the cun, the vacuity and solidity are revealed. This is what is meant.】

    It is said that knowledge from external signs is called sage, while knowledge from internal signs is called spirit; this refers to the same concept.

    【Hua Shou says: Knowing externally refers to observation and listening; knowing internally refers to inquiry and palpation. The spirit is subtle; the sage is clear and insightful. To summarize, the terms sage and spirit suggest that skill is within.】

    In the Sixty-Two Difficulties it is stated: the five organs have five wells and streams, while the six bowels alone have six; what does this mean? Indeed. The bowels are yang, and the three jiaos (heaters) operate among the yang, thus one additional point is established, named yuan (source). The six for the bowels also share a single qi with the three jiaos.

    【Hua Shou says: The five organs' wells and streams signify the junction of channels. The six bowels' wells and streams involve the three jiaos' operation among the yang, hence an additional point is established, named yuan. Therefore, the six for the bowels share a single qi with the three jiaos.】

    【Yu's commentary states: This text seems to have errors and should be cross-referenced with the Sixty-Six Difficulties.】[141p]
    The sixty-third difficulty states: Why are the ten transformations associated with the five organs and six bowels initiated with "井" (well)? Indeed. "井" represents the spring of the East, the beginning of all things. At this time, all creatures stir and breathe; every living thing is born with the spring. Therefore, the numbering of the years starts in spring, and the numbering of the days begins with "甲" (the first of the heavenly stems). Thus, “井” is regarded as the starting point.

    【Hua Shou says: The twelve channels' points are all called "井" (well), and, seeing that “井” is associated with the beginning of the "荥" (bladder meridian) and "俞" (source points), it's because "井" governs the Eastern wood, and wood symbolizes spring, the start of all things. The creatures moving are "行" (to walk), "喘" (to breathe), which means inhaling and exhaling. Gong Sun Hong's transmission states "蚑行喙息," clarifying the meaning. “蜎” signifies flying, while “蠕” pertains to crawling, and both belong to the category of insects. All living things are engendered with spring; hence the counting of years begins with spring, and the counting of days commences with "甲," making the “荥” convergence of humans start with "井" as well.】

    【Feng says: "井" (well) refers to the well from which springs emerge.】

    【Chen from Siming says: The energy of the channels is generated, starting from "井," then flowing into "荥," "俞," passing through channels and converging, thus using the origins of all things, years, and days as a metaphor.】[142p]
    The sixty-fourth difficulty states: The ten transformations further describe yin wells as wood and yang wells as gold; yin rivers as fire and yang rivers as water; yin soil as earth and yang soil as wood; yin channels as gold and yang channels as fire; yin unions as water and yang unions as earth.

    [Hua Shou said: The twelve channels originate from the well cavities. Yin wells correspond to wood, hence yin well wood generates yin river fire, yin river fire generates yin soil earth, yin soil earth generates yin channel gold, and yin channel gold generates yin union water. Yang wells correspond to gold, thus yang well gold generates yang river water, yang river water generates yang soil wood, yang soil wood generates yang channel fire, and yang channel fire generates yang union earth.][143p]
    Yin and Yang are indeed different; what does this mean? It relates to the concepts of hardness and softness. Yin corresponds to the Wood of乙, while Yang corresponds to the Metal of庚. The Yang庚, being庚, represents the hardness of乙; while the Yin乙, being乙, represents the softness of庚.乙 signifies Wood, hence it is referred to as Yin井木;庚 signifies Metal, hence it is referred to as Yang井金. The others follow this pattern.

    [Hua Shou states: Hardness and softness refer to the pairing of乙 and庚. The reason we speak of the ten stems in terms of乙 and庚 is that all vital organs and acupuncture points begin at井. The Yin meridian井 starts with乙木, and the Yang meridian井 starts with庚金, which is why we refer to the pairing of hardness and softness with乙庚, with the other five elements following suit.]

    [Ding remarks: Hardness and softness refer to Yin井木 and Yang井金, where庚金 is hard and乙木 is soft; Yin荥火 and Yang荥水, where壬水 is hard and丁火 is soft; Yin俞土 and Yang俞木, where甲木 is hard and己土 is soft; Yin经金 and Yang经火, where丙火 is hard and辛金 is soft; Yin合水 and Yang合土, where戊土 is hard and癸水 is soft. The principle of the five elements reflects the mother-child relationship in generation, and the husband-wife relationship in overcoming and controlling. Therefore, the path of the husband is always hard, and the path of the wife is always soft; this is the natural order. The Book of Changes states: dividing Yin and Yang and alternating between softness and hardness; is this not the essence of it?][144p]
    The sixty-fifth difficulty states: The classic says that what emerges is the well, and what enters is the union. What is the principle behind this? Indeed. What emerges is the well; the well represents the spring of the East, the beginning of all things coming to life, which is why it is said that what emerges is the well. What enters is the union; the union represents the winter of the North, where the yang energy enters and is stored, which is why it is said that what enters is the union. 【Hua Shou says: This refers to the beginning and end of the flow of the classic's channels.】[145p]
    The sixty-sixth difficulty states: The origin of the lungs is at Taiyuan, the origin of the heart is at Tailing, the origin of the liver is at Taichong, the origin of the spleen is at Taibai, the origin of the kidneys is at Taixi, the origin of the Shaoyin is at Duoguo (also known as Shenmen), the origin of the gallbladder is at Qiuxu, the origin of the stomach is at Chongyang, the origin of the Sanjiao is at Yangchi, the origin of the bladder is at Jinggu, the origin of the large intestine is at Hegu, and the origin of the small intestine is at Wanggu.

    [Shuaishou notes: The lung's original point is Taiyuan, up to the kidney's original point at Taixi, as seen in the first chapter of the "Ling Shu." The second chapter states: the lung's point is Taiyuan, the heart's point is Tailing, the liver's point is Taichong, the spleen's point is Taibai, the kidney's point is Taixi. The bladder's point is Shugu, passing Jinggu to be the origin; the gallbladder's point is Linqi, passing Qiuxu to be the origin; the stomach's point is Xiangu, passing Chongyang to be the origin; the Sanjiao's point is Zhongzhu, passing Yangchi to be the origin; the small intestine's point is Houxi, passing Wanggu to be the origin; the large intestine's point is Sanjian, passing Hegu to be the origin. The five yin organs have their original points defined by their points, while the six yang organs also have points, yet still have separate origins.][146p]
    Some say that the "Lingshu" identifies Tai Ling as the source of the heart, and the "Nanjing" agrees, but also distinguishes the Dui Gu as the source of the lesser yin. Various acupuncture texts treat Tai Ling as the acupuncture point for the hand jueyin heart master, while the Shen Men, located at the end of the Dui Gu on the palm's back, is understood as the point associated with the heart. What accounts for such differences?

    According to the seventy-first chapter of the "Lingshu," if the lesser yin has no outflow, does the heart not suffer? Qibo replies that while the exterior channels are ill, the organs are not ill, hence the focus on the channel at the back of the hand, at the Dui Gu. The other channels rise and fall, with variable speed, similar to the course of the hand lesser yin heart channel. Furthermore, the second chapter states that the heart emerges from Zhong Chong, flows through Lao Gong, reaches Tai Ling, travels through Jian Shi, and enters Qu Ze, coinciding with the hand lesser yin. It follows that points below Zhong Chong are part of the hand heart master channel, and the "Lingshu" explicitly identifies them as hand lesser yin, without separately listing the specific points of the hand lesser yin channel.

    Moreover, the "Suwen" in the section on needle techniques states: needle the end of the hand heart master lesser yin at the Dui Gu, and then one achieves immediate results. In the section on Qi points, it indicates that the five organ points total fifty, with Wang's commentary noting only the heart protector channel's well point, without mentioning the heart channel's well point. Lastly, the seventy-ninth difficulty states: if the heart is ill, drain the hand heart master point, and tonify the hand heart master well point. A thorough examination of the texts shows that the hand lesser yin and the heart master are treated similarly.[147p]
    The twelve meridians are all based on the concept of "yu" (acupoints); why is that? Indeed. The "yu" of the five organs is where the three jiaos operate, where qi is retained and stopped. What is the basis for the "yu" that the three jiaos carry? Indeed. The moving qi between the kidneys below the navel is the essence of human life and the foundation of the twelve meridians; thus, it is called the "yuan" (origin). The three jiaos serve as the special envoy of the "yuan" qi, governing the circulation of the three types of qi, which traverse the five organs and six cavities. The "yuan" is the esteemed title of the three jiaos; therefore, wherever it stops, it is known as the "yuan." In cases where the five organs and six cavities are diseased, all can be traced back to this "yuan."

    [Hua Shou comments: The twelve meridians all rely on "yu" as the foundation because the "yu" of each meridian is connected to the operations of the three jiaos, where qi is retained and stopped. The "yu" that the three jiaos carry is called "yuan," as the moving qi between the kidneys below the navel is indeed the essence of life and the root of the twelve meridians. The three jiaos serve as the special envoy of the "yuan" qi, governing the circulation of the upper, middle, and lower types of qi, which travel through the five organs and six cavities. The circulation of the three types of qi can be understood as the essence of the true original qi from the lower jiao, known as "yuan" qi, which ascends to the middle jiao. The middle jiao receives the essence of water and grains, transforming it into nourishing and protective qi. This nourishing and protective qi communicates with the true original qi and reaches the upper jiao. Thus, "yuan" is the esteemed title of the three jiaos, and wherever it stops, it is referred to as the "yuan," much like how the authorities are referred to in their official titles when they travel. The origin of diseases in the five organs and six cavities is based on this principle. How appropriate!][148p]
    The sixty-seventh difficulty states: The five organ "mu" points are all located in the yin, while the "shu" points are in the yang. What does this mean? Indeed, when yin diseases manifest, they act like yang, and when yang diseases manifest, they act like yin. Hence, the "mu" points are in the yin, and the "shu" points are in the yang.

    [Hua Shou explains: "Mu" and "shu" refer to the collective name for the empty cavities of the five organs. When located in the abdomen, it is called "mu"; when in the back, it is called "shu." "Mu" indicates the collection of qi at this point. In the "Biography of Bian Que," "shu" is written as "shu," meaning to disperse, indicating the qi moves from here to there. The "mu" points of the five organs in the abdomen are: the lung "mu" at the middle palace point, located one inch below the chest's cloud gate, between the second ribs; the heart "mu" at the giant hollow point, located one inch below the end of the sternum; the spleen "mu" at the chapter gate, located below the rib cage straight to the navel; the liver "mu" at the timely gate, located one and a half inches on either side of the center; and the kidney "mu" at the capital gate, located in the lower back beneath the rib cage. The "shu" points of the five organs in the back are along the Gallbladder and Urinary Bladder channels: the lung "shu" is found below the third vertebra, the heart "shu" below the fifth, the liver "shu" below the ninth, the spleen "shu" below the eleventh, and the kidney "shu" below the fourteenth, all located an inch and a half on either side of the spine.

    Yin diseases manifesting as yang and yang diseases as yin indicates that the qi of the yin and yang meridians intersect, linking the organs and abdomen with the back, allowing for communication. Therefore, sometimes yin diseases act like yang, and sometimes yang diseases act like yin. The acupuncture method states: lead from yang to yin, and lead from yin to yang.][149p]
    The sixty-eighth difficulty states: The five viscera and the six bowels all have the channels of well, source, and accumulation, each presiding over different functions. Now, it is said in the channels that the well represents the origin, the source represents the flow, the accumulation represents the storage, the channel represents the function, and the merger represents the entry. The well governs fullness below the heart, the source governs heat in the body, the accumulation governs heavy and painful joints, the channel governs cough and cold symptoms, and the merger governs counterflow and leakage. These are the diseases presided over by the well, source, accumulation, channel, and merger of the five viscera and six bowels.

    【Hua Shou states: To "preside" means to treat. The well represents the source from which water emerges. The source refers to small water flows. Since the original well is subtle, the flow is small and therefore becomes the source. Accumulation refers to transport and storage; it is the result of the source’s flow, thus it is called accumulation. From accumulation to passing through, it is called the channel. From the channel to entering into the merger, it is called the merger, which signifies convergence.】[150p]
    The first section of the "Ling Shu" states: The five zang organs correspond to five points, making a total of twenty-five points; the six fu organs correspond to six points, totalling thirty-six points. [These points refer to the general name for empty cavities. All empty cavities can be referred to as points.] There are twelve primary channels and fifteen collateral channels, making a total of twenty-seven pathways through which qi flows, all linked to the jing, ying, and points, with each associated with different diseases: The jing point corresponds to fullness below the heart, related to liver wood diseases; the ying point corresponds to body heat, related to heart fire diseases; the shu point corresponds to heaviness and joint pain, related to spleen earth diseases; the channel point corresponds to coughing, wheezing, and fluctuating cold and heat, related to lung metal diseases; and the he point corresponds to rebellious qi and leakage, related to kidney water diseases. 【Xie observed: This lists one example of each zang organ's disease, and other diseases can be inferred similarly. The six fu organs are not mentioned since the discussion of the zang is sufficient to encompass them.】[151p]
    The sixty-ninth difficulty states: The classics say that the deficient should be supplemented, the excess should be drained; for that which is neither deficient nor excessive, one should treat it according to the classics. What does this mean? Indeed, the deficient is supplemented by its mother, while the excess is drained from its child. One should first supplement and then drain. For that which is neither deficient nor excessive, treating it according to the classics means that the vital channels themselves are sick, not due to external evils; thus, one should cultivate their own channels, hence the phrase "treating it according to the classics."

    [Hua Shou said: In the tenth chapter of "Ling Shu," it states that for all twelve channels, if they are excessive, drain them; if they are deficient, supplement them; if they are neither excessive nor deficient, treat them according to the classics. The deficient is supplemented by its mother, while the excess is drained from its child; the child can make the mother excessive, and the mother can make the child deficient. For instance, if there is a deficiency in the liver, one should supplement the Jueyin channel; this would be Ququan. If excessive, one should drain the Jueyin channel; this would be Xingjian. One should first supplement and then drain. This refers to conditions of Yang qi being insufficient and Yin qi being excessive; one should first supplement the Yang before draining the Yin. However, this meaning does not belong here; it is either a mistake or a misinterpretation. When it states that it is neither excessive nor deficient and should be treated according to the classics, it pertains to the vital channels’ own sickness, when one is grieved or overly concerned, affecting the heart, or when suffering from cold and consuming cold drinks, which hurts the lungs, and so forth.]

    [Yang said: Neither excessive nor deficient means that the organs do not conflict with each other, thus it is said to cultivate one’s own channels.][152p]
    The "Seventy Difficulties" states: In spring and summer, acupuncture should be shallow, while in autumn and winter, it should be deep. What does this mean? Indeed, in spring and summer, the yang energy is upward, and so is the human vitality; thus, the needle should be inserted shallowly to avoid excessive penetration. In autumn and winter, the yang energy is downward, and so is the human vitality; therefore, the needle should be inserted deeply to ensure it reaches the necessary depth.

    [Hua Shou said: In spring and summer, the yang energy is superficial and ascendant, and so is human vitality; hence, acupuncture should be shallow, aiming for moderation. In autumn and winter, the yang energy is heavy and descending, and so is human vitality; thus, acupuncture should be deep, ensuring sufficient reach. The classics state: "One must first consider the seasonal energies and not disturb the heavenly harmony," which refers to this principle.]

    [From the Chen family of Siming: In spring, the energy resides in the hair, in summer, in the skin, in autumn, in the flesh, and in winter, in the bone marrow; this corresponds to the principles of shallow and deep acupuncture.][153p]
    In spring and summer, the attainment of one yin is essential; similarly, in autumn and winter, the attainment of one yang is necessary. What does this mean? Indeed, in spring and summer, the warmth must lead to one yin; this is achieved by initially needling deeply until reaching the kidney and liver regions to collect and hold the yin energy. Conversely, in autumn and winter, the cold must lead to one yang; this begins with shallow and superficial needling at the heart and lung areas to push and foster the yang energy inward.
